talk.start.para: âIt is with a great deal of pleasure that I rise in support of the motionâmoved by my colleague the member for Calwellâto provide women surviving breast cancer with mammary prostheses through the Medicare rebate. I was first contacted by Dr Linda Reaby OAM, patron of the Caring for You organisation, concerning the placement of mammary prostheses on the Medicare rebate list. I received her letter on 24 June this year and, following immediate discussions with the member for Calwell, we agreed that this was an issue which required the urgent attention of this parliament. I thank also the volunteers from Caring for You for meeting with us last week to further expand on this issue. It was back in 1995 that the then House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs recommended that, as a matter of urgency, the Minister for Human Services and Health amend the Medicare rebate schedule to include the provision of mammary prostheses. To this day, no government has acted on this important recommendation.

speech.para: Members would be aware of the trauma many women, who have survived or are living with breast cancer, live with. Much has been done to increase awareness and reduce the incidence of breast cancer among Australian women. Once a woman has been diagnosed with breast cancer and advised she requires an operation to remove one or both of her breasts, the very least she should expect is to live as normal a life as possible, and the government must support this. It is appalling that the current situation has women using bird seed or old stockings in their bras because they cannot afford the financial burden of mammary prostheses. It is estimated that the number of women undergoing breast cancer surgery in Australia approaches 1,000 each month, with more than one-third requiring a mastectomy. Indeed over a year there are 4,800 women requiring a mastectomy in the course of the treatment of their breast cancer.

The member for Farrer, following some quite well-considered statements, spoke about the provision of the Medicare rebate for breast reconstruction. The average cost of a mammary prostheses is $360. If there are 4,800 women affected each year, the cost to Medicare would be just over $1.7 million. Compare this to breast reconstruction, which is currently free in the public health system. Reconstruction on average costs $7,000 per breast. So 4,800 breast reconstructions cost Medicare around $33.6 million per year. We are comparing a cost of just $1.7 million per year for prostheses to $33.6 million per year for breast reconstructions.

At this point in time, of these women requiring mammary prostheses, 70 per cent cannot afford to purchase them at the time of fitting, 10 per cent are wearing bird seed or similar makeshift prostheses, one per cent choose not to wear any form of prosthesis and a staggering 91 per cent are wearing damaged, old, incorrect sized, hand-me-down prothesesâor protheses from deceased peopleâfrom family or handouts from local health agencies. Because of the costs, there are also many women who, after acquiring a mammary prosthesis, resort to repairing their prostheses rather than replacing them after two years of use so as not to burden their family budgets. As we heard, women are using many means of repair, including band-aids, sticky tape, glue and any other means at their disposal. These figures have been compiled by the Caring for You organisation.

While preparing this contribution, I spoke with Penny Dudding from the You Really are Beautiful shop in Newcastle. Penny set up the shop seven years ago because of the high number of women who do not even know about mammary prostheses. Penny told me that, though most of her clients are between 40 and 70 years of age, over the past seven years they have been getting younger. She said of her clients that approximately 30 per cent would have private health cover, 50 per cent were using the public system and 20 per cent would be covered by the NSW PADP system. Penny gave me the recent example of a 31-year-old woman who is currently six weeks down the track from having surgery. She has a nine-week-old baby. She had her operation in a private hospital, under private health insurance, and then discovered that the provision of a prosthesis was not covered by her health insurance.

Many women who lose or partially lose a breast suffer tremendous psychological effects because breasts are seen by society as symbols of femininity and sexuality. Arguably, the provision of mammary prostheses is as important a part of breast cancer treatment as chemotherapy or radiation. Given the large number of affected women and the seriousness of this issue, the government must support the needs of women who have fought and won or continue to fight the horrors of breast cancer. We must now fight to ensure this vital part of breast cancer treatment is available to all those women who have survived or are still fighting breast cancer. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to speak on this motion today on the provision of mammary protheses for women who have suffered from breast cancer. There may be some members in the House who find it unusual that a man would wish to speak on an important issue such as this, but it is something that affects all men and women in a partnership. If a woman discovers a lump in her breast, hopefully her partner will be supportive as she awaits the results of tests and the concerns that go with it. Thankfully, in most cases, the tests turn out to be successful and the results are benign, and life goes on as normalâbut it does not always happen that way. It must be a very traumatic and terrible time for couples when women are diagnosed with breast cancer.

speech.para: In some ways I can relate to that, because it is an issue that affects both men and women. About 12 years ago, I discovered a lump on the right side of my chest and, like most men, delayed going to the doctor for some time, until it became obvious that I had to have something done. Very quickly, I found myself undergoing surgery. I spent four days lying in hospital with a drainage tube hanging out of my chest, contemplating my future and awaiting the results of those tests. So I am very keen to support the women who suffer from breast cancer. The trauma and the concerns that I went through are nothing compared to what they go through, but I hope that, by saying that publicly, people will realise that it is an issue of concern to me.

I am very pleased to continue the discussions on who should fund these prostheses. It is an important issue. I am pleased that the federal minister has said that she certainly would be happy for the Commonwealth to discuss the funding of these prostheses with the states within the context of the Australian health care agreements. I know that the minister is aware that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs recommended that the medical benefits schedule should be widened to include breast prostheses. I welcome the findings of that standing committee. The Medicare benefit arrangements were designed to provide assistance to people who incur medical expenses in relation to professional services rendered by qualified medical practitioners. That is why Medicare benefits are not payable for aids or appliances, including breast prostheses. I believe that the need for women to have breast prosthesesâand I am not a medical professionalâis really a medical issue and women should be entitled to them. Every woman, no matter what her income or background, should be entitled to the dignity and the availability of these prostheses. It is important to find a satisfactory resolution to this concern.

I am advised that some private health insurers rebate the cost of these prostheses as part of their ancillary cover, and I welcome the fact that people can privately insure for this. But the fundamental issue is that the funding of these prostheses for public patients in hospitals is a matter for the state and territory health departments. I know it frustrates people when they are in need of a breast prosthesis or some other health care to see governments arguing as to whether the federal government or the state governments should pay, but it is an undeniable fact that the Commonwealth government has provided unprecedented growth in funding for hospitals during the current five-year Medicare agreement. Over the five years of the life of this agreement, which ends next year, the Commonwealth will have increased its support for public hospital services by around 28 per cent. That is very important, but it is cold comfort for those women who are seeking support to enable them to have a breast prosthesis.

I certainly will continue discussions with the minister and with the government on this issue. I urge all state and territory governments, which are given the resources from the Commonwealth government to provide assistance with breast prostheses, to look sympathetically at this very important issue which affects Australian men and women. I appreciate the opportunity that has been available to me to speak on this motion.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)âOrder! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

motion.para: That grievances be noted.

subdebateinfo.title: Hasluck Electorate: Natural Heritage Trust Funding

talk.start.para: âI wish to raise an important matter today that ultimately threatens the viability of the Swan and Canning rivers and their environs in the Perth metropolitan area. I have previously told the House about the magnificent work being done by community land care and natural resource management groups in the Swan region. The Swan region includes my electorate of Hasluck, as well as the electorates of Canning, Tangney and Pearce in the Perth metropolitan and peri-urban areas. There are 17 catchment groups and over 200 other environmental groups operating in the region. They represent many thousands of community volunteers. I am amazed at and thankful for the ability of these groups and their coordinators to attract volunteers from the community to become involved in land care activities in the region. I am not aware of any other program or project that has captured the energy or the hearts and minds of so many volunteers, and I have been particularly privileged to visit many of the projects that have been undertaken by these groups in my electorate. The reason I rise to speak today is the fear that those groups and I share that the funding they receive for the continued coordination of their projects within the electorate of Hasluck is at risk.

speech.para: I would like to take some time to cover the information that I have received. Firstly, in answer to a dorothy dix question last week, the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry acknowledged the work of these very same volunteers and commented about community Landcare projects. Of course, it was National Landcare Week, and perhaps that is why he chose not to reveal what appears to be the truth about the current uncertainty of NHT extension funding to urban community Landcare and natural resource management groups. These groups receive funding for their projects from a variety of sources: the private sector, federal, state and local governments, as well as the community itself. However, their major source of funding, particularly that which resources the employment of the 11 community Landcare coordinators currently employed in the Swan region, comes from the Natural Heritage Trust. Their funding ceases in Septemberâjust next week.

The Natural Heritage Trust was heralded by this government as a billion-dollar investment over five yearsâapproximately $200 million per annum. In recent budget papers the figure of $250 million was put forward, allegedly for NHT funding. That is not the only reference we have had to this funding. Indeed, on 14 May 2002 a joint press release was made by the two ministers who have some responsibility for NHT fundingâthe Minister for the Environment and Heritage and the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. In that press release, Dr Kemp tells us:

quote.para: At least $350 million of the new Trust funding will be spent directly on measures to improve water quality. For example, Rivercare projects will support improved land and water practices that affect the health of our rivers. Coastcare and Rivercare funding will also target coastal and urban water quality hot spots such as the Parramatta River, Moreton Bay, Port Adelaide, the Derwent Estuary, Port Phillip Bay, the Cooks and Georges Rivers andâ

speech.para: importantly, I might addâ

quote.para: the Swan/Canning Rivers.

speech.para: That is the very area that I am talking about today.

As I said earlier, the minister referred to the funding for NHT in answer to a question he gave last week. He claimed that this government had made a $2.5 billion commitment to the Natural Heritage Trust. With these figures of $250 million, $2.5 billion and $350 million being thrown around, you can imagine my surprise when I heard the figures that community Landcare groups in my electorate have been advised of by senior bureaucrats responsible for NHT funding. They have been told by those bureaucrats that much less money will be made available than has been publicly indicated by the government. Current estimates from these friendly visiting bureaucrats indicate that in truth the government is considering making only between $50 million and $100 million available in this interim year. Remember that the government has promised at least between $200 million and $250 million, depending on which press release you read or which minister you are talking toâsubstantially less than what has been promised.

Compounding this problem are the current guidelines for the coordination and facilitation stream for the transitional year of the NHT, which I might say is the source of the funding for the 11 community coordinator positions in the Swan region. The guidelines state that priority will be for positions that provide support for rural community groups engaged in Landcare and sustainable agricultural activities. I do not denigrate the need for funding to be directed to rural communities for Landcare projectsâquite the contrary. However, as Pat Hart, who is the chairperson of the Canning Catchment Co-ordinating Group in my electorate, said to me in her letter:

quote.para: We also have grave concerns at the proposed reduction in funding ... for urban Landcare groups. We acknowledge the major issue with salinity in our rural areas and recognise the urgency. We also recognise the huge environmental problems facing the Swan/Canning catchments where we have 1.3 million people located on a relatively small area. A very fragile, ancient landscape that has major environmental problems. In the Canning Catchment we have seen major blue/green algae outbreaks, wetland destruction on a major scale and severe dieback impact on bushland. The Canning River identified as the worst weed affected river in the State with severe loss of aquatic species. The Canning/Wungong/Southern Rivers suffering severe silting and loss of natural flow. There are grave concerns also by catchment coordinators with their future positions ... The incredible impact of the educational and awareness programs implemented by these groups should not be underestimated. The continuation of these programs is critical to ensure real positive environmental changes. To take away these programs will set the catchment back years and will mean a real financial loss through the work already put into their management. Outstanding achievements are, and have occurred through Urban Catchment Groups.

speech.para: That is why I rise today, and those are the issues that I particularly want to put on the record about this Natural Heritage Trust funding. It is time, I thinkâand I call on the governmentâto be honest about the situation for NHT funding for urban Landcare groups.

What are the arrangements for these programs in capital cities and large regional centres in other parts of Australia? Is Western Australia being treated in a less equitable manner than other states? And what has the government got to say about the so-called partnership between government and the community in natural resource management? What value is a partnership when the federal government feel that they can walk away with no regard for or commitment to projects well under way? Are they expecting that the costs for these projects will be picked up either by state governments or by local governments and the community itself? How ironic that we have this government holding an inquiry into state government allegedly cost shifting to local government when here is a classic example of the federal government doing the same thing. How dare they make public calls for priority projects under new arrangements and let the bureaucrats go out there and tell people that there will not be enough money to fund them. How credible can a government be that calls publicly for projects and yet does not or will not make the commitment to fund them? And, if there are funds made available through the Envirofund stream, what community groups are going to be left to implement them?

The work of the communityâwho have contributed, as I have said, many thousands of voluntary hours over seven years, having been supported by government projectsâis likely to be wasted if their funding is not continued. It also runs contrary to the kinds of commitments that have been made to these groups by various ministers, most recently in correspondence in late May, where, in a letter to the Chairperson of the Swan Catchment Council, Mr Michael Grasby, Minister David Kemp said:

quote.para: Mr Truss and I understand your views on the importance of urban Landcare projects and wish to emphasise that the government is committed to ensuring that these projects continue to be supported under the extension of the trust.

speech.para: If that is the case, where is the funding? I would say that the overall administration of the transition from NHT to the Natural Heritage Trust extension has been lacking in leadership and direction and, frankly, at a policy level, is downright inept. I urge the government to support the Swan Canning catchment region and their urban Landcare coordinators.

talk.start.para: âI raise a matter in this grievance debate concerning allegations made by the member for Hunter during last Thursday's adjournment debate. Firstly, I would like to thank the member for Hunter for his confidence in my powers as a local member. The member made allegations that I was responsible for the sacking of Arch Humphrey from the position of Chair of the Hunter Area Consultative Committee for retribution for a project that did not receive funding. I do not know what powers the member for Hunter thinks local members have, but local members do not have the power to personally sack someone from a position such as chair of an area consultative committee. That is the sole responsibility of the department. I understand that Mr Humphrey served three 12-month terms as a chair; perhaps the department thought it was time for a fresh direction. I only ever had discussions with departmental officials after Mr Humphrey was dismissed and not before that.

speech.para: There are many area consultative committees around the country, which play an important role in facilitating partnerships with government. In my electorate of Paterson, which has been heavily affected by dairy deregulation in Gloucester and Dungog, the Hunter Area Consultative Committee and the Mid-North Coast Area Consultative Committee work with communities to find projects that will create employment opportunities in the area.

This is really the heart of my grievance. This is about jobs and creating jobsâsomething that Labor has a very poor record on, particularly when you look at unemployment rates in the Hunter. It should be of no surprise that the business community warms to the coalition, because the coalition has delivered outstanding economic conditions for business growth. The Howard government's management of the economy has produced an environment that supports business growth including, in particular, historically low interest rates and continuing low inflation. This ensures that Australia is largely protected from the external shocks that have so destabilised other economies in our region. Sound management of the Australian economy allows businesses to get on with what they do bestânamely, running their businessesâconfident that the economic policy settings will provide a solid underpinning for forward growth plans.

This leads me to allegations made by the member for Hunter concerning Mr Joe Sepos from Sepos Transport. Mr Sepos is a very successful businessman and, like other business operators, he talks to the coalition because the coalition supports policies that support small businesses such as his. Mr Sepos was looking to invest in the electorate of Paterson and, in particular, in the town of Dungog in a project that involved setting up a tyre retreading facility and a stock crate manufacturing unit. I mentioned earlier that Dungog has been severely affected by dairy deregulation. The creation of jobs in this town is vital for its future and to support the existing economy. Mr Sepos's interest in investing in Dungog arose when I was the Liberal candidate for Paterson. As an advocate for supporting job creation and employment opportunities in the area, it is no surprise that I contacted the Hunter Area Consultative Committee to see if this project would be eligible for funding under the Dairy Regional Assistance Program.

On 22 October, I took Mr Sepos to meet with the Mayor of Dungog Shire Council, Steve Low, other councillors, Barry Ryan, the Mayor of Gloucester Shire Council, and others to look at the possibility of site selection for the project. After this, I spoke to Arch Humphrey, the then chair, about the project. He directed me to talk to Kath Elliot, the CEO of the Hunter Area Consultative Committee. I was advised that Mr Sepos should contact them directly to discuss the matter. The amazing thing about this allegation of the member for Hunter is that Sepos Transport did not even put in to the minister a formal application for funding. It turned out to be cheaper for his business to import retreaded tyres rather than make them locally. It was clearly a business decision that stopped Sepos Transport further pursuing government funding. Sepos Transport also directly approached state bodies on this project, which advised them to contact the Hunter Area Consultative Committee about Dairy RAP funding.

The member for Hunter's allegation that I harassed members of the Hunter Area Consultative Committee to try to obtain funding for the project is ridiculous and is an insult. In fact, it is a blatant lie and misleads the parliament. Is it wrong that the area consultative committee is asked to look at a project that will create jobs in an area? I do not think so. If you asked people whether representatives should push for more projects that will create local jobs, most would say yes. People expect local representatives to bring to government projects and ideas to create jobs. I saw this project as an opportunity to create jobs for the area, so I sought the advice of HACC on this issue. Asking for direction on a project can hardly be called harassment, and it is probably something that the member for Hunter needs to do to bring down the unemployment rates in areas in his own electorate, like Cessnock.

The allegation that I was seeking retribution for a project that did not receive funding is quite ridiculous, given that the business made a business decision not to pursue funding. How can I seek retribution for a project that did not receive funding if the people behind the project decided not to put in an application for funding in the first place? What is interesting about this is that the former member for Paterson called Mr Sepos when it was announced that Sepos was looking at investing in the local area. The former member was disappointed that he was not involved in the announcement. The simple fact is, though, that Sepos Transport wanted the backing of a party that supports small business. Sepos Transport is like many companies that know Labor does not support policies that support small businesses, and the coalition has an outstanding record on this issue. The member for Hunter, who was shadow minister for small business at the time, has shown little support for or understanding of small business. The proof of that lies in the fact that Labor has blocked unfair dismissal laws 19 times since 1996. If the Labor Party wants the support of small businesses, it is time it started supporting policies that enable small businesses like those in the Hunter to grow.

In addition, the member for Hunter raised an allegation that I spoke to a minister or a department about the sacking of Mr Humphrey for retribution for Mr Sepos's project not receiving funding. Sepos Transport made the inquiries themselves about various government funding programs, including state programs. I can and do talk to ministers and their officers about projects that I am aware have put in applications for funding, and there are many projects that I have written to the minister about concerning funding under the Dairy Regional Assistance Program.

I am more than happy to promote and lobby for local projects, and that is exactly what every local member should be doing. If people come to me with an application for funding under any Commonwealth, state or local program, I am more than happy to support the application. Does the member for Hunter really think that in a marginal seat such as Paterson I have the time to be scheming about who should or should not be on the boards of every single committee in the Hunter Valley? As for the allegation that I wanted Mr Humphrey removed and replaced by Mr Bob Geoghegan, it is, again, a complete joke. As a Maitland councillor, as the owner and operator of a very successful small business and as a great Liberal candidate for the state seat of Maitland, Mr Geoghegan has his hands too full to even consider such a role.

Finally, there was also an allegationâand there were liesâthat there was an inappropriate arrangement between Mr Geoghegan and me over the leasing arrangements for a building for my office when I was the member for Paterson between 1996-98. I refer to a letter from McDonald Johnson Solicitors to Mr Geoghegan, dated 25 November 1995, about entering into an agreement to lease a building to Hills Solicitors. Hills Solicitors' architect, Andrew Pender, assisted in the design of the building for Hills's requirements. Late in 1997âafter the building was builtâwhen Hills did not proceed with the lease as they had chosen another office on the site, I became aware that it was available for lease, and I requested the Department of Finance and Administration to pursue it as an option in October 1997. The claims by the member for Hunter that I moved to these offices from High Street Maitland in 1996 are false, as I did not relocate until January 1998, after the building was built. Furthermore, documents show that negotiations on the lease of this building by Hills Solicitors started in November 1995, well before the 1996 election when I became the member for Paterson. But, more importantly, it is the Department of Finance and Administration that administers and negotiates leases on behalf of government; it is not local members. I think it is quite clear, from the points I have made today, that the member for Hunter drew a long bow with the allegations he made in parliament last week and that he has misled and lied to the parliament.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)âOrder! The honourable member for Paterson has used the word `lie' on two occasions now. I missed the first one and will have to revisit it. The member for Paterson would know that the chair does not like the word `lie'. It is blatantly against the standing orders and has to be withdrawn.
âIf that is the case, I will withdraw the word `lie' and replace it with `blatantly mishandled the truth'.
âWe must revisit the other instance where you made allegations about a statement being a lie, which was earlier in your speechâ
âYes.
âIf it was a reference to the member for Hunter, it must be withdrawn as well.
âI will withdraw it and replace it with `mishandled the truth recklessly'.
âI think that is a little over the top, too. I think you could probably find a better word.
âThe member for Hunter has blatantly gone out and misrepresented the truth to this House. He needs to apologise to the House for the accusations he has made against me as the member for Paterson.
âI ask the member for Paterson to withdraw the references to `lie' in his speech.
âI will withdraw the references to `lie'.
âThank you.
âAnd I seek to replace them with `blatantly mishandled the truth'. (Time expired)

âI grieve for the rise of the new political correctnessâthe hypocritical demand of the conservative establishment in this country for civility in political debate. Imagine the hide of these peopleâthe old money interests, the conservative think tanks, the Tory MPs and their fellow travellers in the commercial media. They have spent the last 20 years hopping into the unemployed, Aboriginal communities, newly arrived migrants and anyone else at the bottom of the social ladder, and now they want civility. This is the height of hypocrisy. They want civility on just one side of the political fence: the sort of civility by which George Pell is automatically declared innocent, while Justice Michael Kirby and other social reformers are slandered in the Senate; the sort of civility whereby big business is allowed to regulate itself, while the rest of society receives a truckload of mutual obligation; the sort of civility where the work ethic of the royal family is beyond question, while the member for Warringah can call young unemployed Australians `job snobs'. For the establishment, civility is a way of preserving the social pecking order. It helps the ruling class to avoid public scrutiny and accountability. It tells working people to accept their lot in life, without challenging the power and privilege of the Tory elite. This is a new political correctness, where sameness is embraced and rebellion is written off as rude. The old political correctness, with its unspoken truths and protection of special interests, was bad enough; the new one is twice as bad. It threatens to turn us into a nation of robots, without the irreverence and daring that have always defined our national character. Bit by bit, it is chipping away at our cultural identity, eroding the great Australian traditions of larrikinism and mateship.

speech.para: For the Tories, civility is important for another reason: it is code for the re-election of the Howard government. The conservative establishment is trying to turn this government into a protected species, beyond criticism and beyond condemnation. No matter how many times the Prime Minister hugs the Americans or tugs his forelock to the royal family, the establishment will defend him and then have the hide to claim that the Howard government is protecting Australia's national sovereignty. This is the defining characteristic of Tory politics: double standardsâled by the member for Warringah. He says that he supports community based politics, yet he has an obsessive hatred of Australia's largest community based organisation, the trade union movement. He claims that the ALP is no longer a working-class party, yet he had kittens when I used a great working-class term to describe the Prime Minister's sycophancy toward the United States.
Indeed, the establishment was out in force on that issue. In the Daily Telegraph, Michael Duffy said:

quote.para: No matter how they try to justify the language they use, Crean and Latham are basically just letting the public see how blokes in the Labor Party and the unions talk all the time.

speech.para: In the Sydney Morning Herald, Paddy McGuinness called it `a vulgar attack on the Prime Minister'. Piers Akerman called it a `linguistic shortcoming'. Michael Duffy, Paddy McGuinness and Paddington Piers are the same people who have been claiming for a decade that Labor no longer represents the values and language of working-class Australians. They are the same people who complain about the chattering classes and other elites, yet they cannot stand the sound of Australian slang. This simply exposes their cant and hypocrisy.

Civility is the new establishment catchcry. Writing in the Australian newspaper, Janet Albrechtsen said that she found parents barracking for their children at Saturday morning sport, `having a go at the ref, yelling abuse' to be morally offensive. The Minister for Education, Science and Training piously repeated this view in parliament last week. This is typical of the Tories, trying to take the passion and commitment out of life, reducing us to a culture of conformity where we no longer challenge authority figures. They want to take the irreverence and spark out of the Australian character and turn us into a nation of conservative clones. According to their world view, people should be one dimensional, passively accepting their place in society.

On the Labor side of politics, we believe in the richness of human natureâthat social stability need not be incompatible with the values of compassion and creativity. Albrechtsen and Dr Nelson fail to understand that the parents who take their children to sport and passionately support them are the good parents, the ones who care, the ones who are most likely to look out for and assist the kids in need. The minister for education may be a bland and passionless character himselfâin most respects, unAustralianâbut he should not expect other people to lead their lives this way. What sort of society would we be if parents did not feel emotional about their children? People are not one dimensional. Social cohesion, compassion and creativity can coexist.

Albrechtsen is another filthy hypocrite. Who is she to lecture people on civility? She is someone who hates feminism, describing other women as `totalitarian' and `self-obsessed' just because they support paid maternity leave. She is someone who uses terms such as `F...wittage' in her columns. So much for civility.

This is the great fraud of Australian politics. When Pauline Hanson gave her maiden speech in this place, heaping abuse on Asians, Aborigines and anyone else different to her, the Prime Minister said that the era of political censorship had ended. Now the Tories are trying to impose their own form of censorshipâa new political correctness that defends the political interests of the Howard government. There is, of course, nothing civil about the government's electoral strategy. It aims to turn Australians against each other through the politics of division. This is a replica of the culture war in the United States, the type of strategy that inspired Pat Buchanan to write the following memo to Richard Nixon in the late 1960s: `We should tear the country in two and then pick up the bigger piece politically.' A similar piece of thinking is now on the public record in this country. Last month Paul Kelly interviewed the Prime Minister on his 63rd birthday and subsequently wrote:

quote.para: Howard is going to focus on social policy this term and set out to smash the post-Whitlam political alliance between the working class and the tertiary-educated Left that defines modern Labor. The refugee issue severed this alliance at the 2001 poll and Howard will follow up with new campaigns.

speech.para: In fact, the progressive consensus in Australian politics is holding up remarkably well. Whether people live in the inner city or the outer suburbs, they want greater social investment in education and health. So, too, they want a more sustainable urban environment, with less congestion and pollution. On social policy, even the member for Warringah has conceded there is little public support for winding back Australia's abortion and divorce laws or reversing the many progressive gains achieved by women in recent decades.

If the Prime Minister is to smash the progressive consensus in this country, he will target questions of race and responsibility. Twelve months ago today, when they came together on the Tampa, they divided the nation. As the Prime Minister demonstrated in the 1980s, racism is always lurking just below the surface of conservative politics. It is a feature of the Tory newspaper columnists: examples include Akerman's current campaign against Australian Muslims and attempts by the little bigot, Mike Gibson, to slag Asian and negro athletes. I have no doubt that the establishment is gearing up for further campaigns based on race and responsibility. Indeed, the Tory dogs of war are mobilising against multiculturalism. They see this as a spin-off from Tampa and September 11.

When Australia's leading neoconservative think tank, the Centre for Independent Studies, focuses on an issue, it is a sign that the Howard government will soon follow. Last year the CIS sponsored lectures by Vaclav Klaus in which he attacked the European ideal. Such was the intensity of his ultranationalism, it was like an echo from 1914 or 1939. In the November issue of Quadrant, the CIS Senior Fellow, Wolfgang Kasper, advocated a return to racially based immigration policies under the banner of `cultural transaction costs'. Earlier this year the CIS hosted a speaking tour by Daniel Pipes, the American anti-Islamic campaigner who equates Islamic law with Stalinism. The policy direction is clear, but so too is the hypocrisy. Ironically enough, the CIS has joined the civility campaign. It is a terrible shame, however, that this civility does not extend to European internationalists, Muslims or people who are culturally different to Wolfgang Kasper.

The government is also engaged in a double standard. At the last election it said, `We decide who comes into this country and under what conditions.' Yet in other areas of public policy it allows foreigners to call the shots. It allows Australia's foreign policy to be determined in Washington. When the Americans say jump, the Prime Minister asks: `How high?' On constitutional reform, its stance is determined in London. The member for Warringah was born in Britain and always puts British interests first. Recently he also spoke of the Catholicisation of the Liberal Party. Some people thought this was a reference to the way in which Piers Akerman, Nancy Boy Bolt and Christopher Pearson act as press secretaries for both the Howard government and George Pell. In fact, the member for Warringah outlined a new and more significant trend in Liberal policy making. Catholicisation means that the Liberal Party's social policies are being determined in Rome. This is the ultimate hypocrisy. The government may decide who comes into the country but, increasingly, its other policies are being decided in Washington, London and Rome.

By contrast, Labor is anti-establishment. We aim to help the outsiders, those disenfranchised by the Tory network of businessmen, think tanks, media lackeys and coalition MPs. As far as I am concerned, if you want civility in Canberra, buy a parrot.

talker.name: Kelly, Jackie, MP
Miss JACKIE KELLY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âToday I would like to speak on a very important issue that affects not only my electorate of Lindsay but the broader region of Western Sydney, of which the member for Werriwa's seat is a part. He touched ever so briefly on it in his grievance. The issue that I raise a grievance about is how the people of Western Sydney will live in the futureâit is an issue of lifestyle.

speech.para: Western Sydney has come a long way from a largely rural population of 627,000 to what is now the third largest economy in Australia, behind Sydney and Melbourne. Western Sydney now has a population of 1.74 million. According to the census data released earlier this year, Penrith, which is part of my electorate, has one of the largest populations of nought- to five-year-olds in the country. The mayor of Penrith has recently been quoted as saying the Penrith area's population has grown by 400 per cent in 40 years and that it would have 50,000 more people in the next 20 years. These figures underline the fact that Western Sydney is an important area of growth. With a four-month-old and a two-year-old, I am guilty of adding to this demographic. I would like them to own a home in the area when they grow up, to be a part of my life and to live close by, but only if it offers them a lifestyle that is the same as, or better than, the one I enjoy. This is where I take issue with the inability of our planning authorities to keep pace with this growth.

There is little doubt that many planning mistakes have been made in New South Wales, and a lot of them have been made in Western Sydney. All levels of government can be blamed, but the responsibility for planning lies largely with the state government and, to a smaller degree, with local government. And it is the state and local governments that continue to make the same mistakes. There seems to be no corporate knowledge of past errors in planning, and major mistakes are being repeated. For example, at Homebush, Newington offers many things, but not sufficient parking for the residents' cars, let alone visitors' cars.

The New South Wales government seem to have a penchant for filling my electorate and others in Western Sydney with houses, turning Western Sydney into a big dormitory suburb. They do this with no thought for providing those new residents with infrastructure such as schools, child care, hospitals or transport required for an enjoyable lifestyle. Perhaps their biggest planning mistake is not providing for employment. Whilst my electorate is enjoying some of the lowest unemployment it has ever known, thanks largely to the policies of the Howard government, too many people in my electorate travel up to four hours each day just getting to and from work. This takes them away from home from seven in the morning until seven at night, thereby missing valuable and enjoyable parenting hours. After seven each evening children tend to be a bit fractious and unreasonable, and it is really time for quiet and strict parenting rather than for loud, interactive fun times.

Before the last election, the state government planned to build 8,000 houses on endangered Cumberland Plain woodland on the former ADI site at St Marys. It was not until this government stepped in that these plans were scuttled somewhat by ensuring that the entire 828 hectares of Cumberland Plain woodland on the site would be protected. It also happened that this extra land for the regional park was over the top of what had been proposed to be land for jobs. So what is happening is that that land has gone and no more land is being found for jobs. The Department of Planning is quite happy to proceed with the project, using the remaining land for houses, with no further land for jobs.

In December, the New South Wales Minister for Urban Affairs and Planning, Dr Andrew Refshauge, released a further 17,000 acres for development in my electorate and in that of my colleague the member for Macarthur. This land was not released to develop roads, schools or public transport; it was definitely not released to create long-term employment. And there were no hospitals. This land was released to build another 89,000 houses. There are different state departments for health, education, planning, public transport and roads, and herein lies the problem. The New South Wales government has a fragmented approach to development. It seems that everyone has a responsibility but no-one is responsible for ensuring the overall effect is a nice lifestyle in Western Sydney and not a rabbit warren existence similar to that of inner city residents who need a permit to parkâif they can find oneâand where visitors pay for parking.

I am not the first person to recognise this problem. As is often the case when those opposite leave politics, they begin to speak sense and learn the error of their ways. Former Deputy Prime Minister Brian Howe, in the journal Australian Planner of 2001, said:

quote.para: Indeed it was often the case that major infrastructure followed development rather than shaping it and the approach of governments tended to be fragmented and poorly coordinated.

speech.para: The state Carr government still has this fragmented approach to development, preferring to leave the Lend Leases, Macquaries and Mirvacs responsible for building the communities of the future. Is it appropriate for private enterprise, major international companies with the capital to invest in these large housing estates, to be responsible for the communities they build or the communities that surround those new housing estates? They answer to shareholders, who demand a return for their investment. Perhaps there should be a code of conduct for such company developments. The employees of these companies who design these `communities of the future' live in the inner city or, even worse, interstate. They do not understand what it is to have to travel up to four hours each day just to get to and from work, and they do not understand what pressure this travel time places on families, especially those with young children.

In all the time that I have been discussing these issues with these so-called planners, I have discovered one thing: I am the only person they have spoken to who comes from Western Sydney. These people do not speak to the people that I do, the people I meet on the train stations very early in the morningsâfrom six onwardsâand the people who kiss and ride at seven in the morning and who do not see their children again until they are getting ready for bed. Again, they are missing invaluable parenting time. With dual income families, it gets more distressing: weekends become ever more precious, and the community as a whole is then pressed for a lot of those community hours that were generally available between a couple to give to the community on weekends. At this moment, we are spending it all parenting. The people who are designing these so-called communities do not understand what it is like to live in the communities they design. Again, there is a lack of corporate knowledge.

What government needs is a coordinated approach, one that takes into account the way that people actually live their lives and how they would like their children to live equally enjoyable lives. Not many people want to spend four hours each day travelling to and from work. We need to be planning employment for the thousands of people who are moving to areas such as Western Sydney. We need to be planning housing estates with wide streets sufficient for the cars that come with the family lifestyle that we have in Western Sydney and the penchant that people in Western Sydney have for the motor vehicle, given the appalling lack of public transport in the area. At best, there is a drive to the railway station and then public transport to your place of employment. If you are working and you want to pick up the kids and stop off to get some groceries on the way home then, really, the car is the only way to go. Most houses in Western Sydney tend to contain dual car families, if not more if you have adult or teenage sons. Again, in these new estates you need parking that delivers on that. We have a high number of self-employed in the trucking industry and, again, a lot of these estates are not providing parking for our workers' trucks.

I suggest to Bob Carr, the Premier of New South Wales, that he bring all these issues into a central agency, an agency that brings planning, health, education and transport together. I am proposing that he establish, effectively, a ministry for lifestyle that oversees everything that is going ahead so that you cannot have one department rolling out 89,000 houses and another department not simultaneously rolling out the hospital care to cater for the people who will come to those houses or the roads department not rolling out the high-speed networks that will be needed for those 89,000 households and the education department also not rolling out the schools for the public education that will be required for those 89,000 households. The issue has reached crisis point. I encourage Bob Carr to call a tri-level seminar for all levels of government to approach this problem and find a solution for Western Sydney.

talk.start.para: âI grieve today for the failure of the Howard government to design and implement a comprehensive long-term policy to deal with refugee and asylum seeker issues. I am sure it would not have escaped the House's attention that today is the anniversary of the commencement of the Tampa incident. The Tampa incident started on 26 August last year when a routine surveillance flight by Coastwatch revealed the presence of a vessel approximately 80 nautical miles north-west of Christmas Island. This vessel was the KM Palapa, which was carrying 433 potential asylum seekers en route to Australia before it broke down. We all know what happened after that, but I ask the House to speculate what would have happened had the KM Palapa not broken down but successfully reached Ashmore Reef or Christmas Island. I suggest, in those circumstances, that the Howard government would have done no more than what it did with respect to the 213 boats that arrived earlier, between the election of the Howard government and the day that the Palapa was picked up by Australian Coastwatch. We know that in respect of those boatsâsome 213 boats carrying 11,513 peopleâthe Howard government did nothing. We need to paint the picture here, because these arrivals included arrivals on the eastern coast of Australia, including one near Townsville, one near Scotts Head on the mid-north coast of New South Wales and one as far south as Port Kembla. This was an increasing and visible problem.

speech.para: In the face of this increasing and visible problem, the Howard government did very little at all, even though it had to have known from intelligence reports that the forthcoming wave of boat people was eminently foreseeable. Known and identifiable factors relating to the likelihood of boat arrivals included: a closing of borders in European countries; the consolidation of Taliban rule in Afghanistan from 1995-96 onwards; continuing oppression in Iraq; easier and cheaper travel and advances in worldwide communications technology facilitating travel and the knowledge of destinations; and the growth of people-smuggling with people smugglers promoting Australia as a next best destination to Europe. All of these things were well known, and yet the Howard government seemed caughtâstunnedâwhen all these identifiable and knowable factors translated into unauthorised arrivals. In the face of these unauthorised arrivals, the Howard government did nothing except maintain Labor's policy of mandatory detention.

The Howard government did not take any of the actions required to address the issues. It did not do anything to improve our coastal surveillance or to detect and smash people-smuggling rings, it did not do anything in the global or regional debate to deal with the emerging problem, it did not review any of its aid programs to see whether it could ameliorate the reasons that were causing people to move and it did not expand any of the processing resources in transit countries. Indeed, the enormity of the Howard government's failure is starkly shown by the fact that it was not until May 2000 that the government bothered to focus on people-smuggling through the establishment of a joint DIMIA-Australian Federal Police strike team.

But the arrival of the Palapaâthe boat carrying the people then rescued by the Tampaâwas too good a political opportunity to miss. In the face of that political opportunity, while behind in the polls and about to face an election, the Howard government hastily contrived what has become known as the Pacific solution. It is very important that we understand what the Pacific solution truly is, because it suits this government to place under that umbrella all the initiatives it has hastily scrambled around to cobble together since the arrival of the Tampa and since its decision to deal with this issue in an electoral context. The bundle of policies that it has engaged in since that time include, for example, the deployment of Operation Relexâthe naval blockadeâand increased Australian Federal Police resources in Indonesia. Properly viewed, neither of those things is contingent on the so-called Pacific solution, which is the detention and processing of people in third countries in the Pacific.

Labor supports coastal security. It believes that it can be done in a better and more sustainable way than Operation Relex, through a purpose specific coastguard. Labor supports the deployment of Australian Federal Police in Indonesia and increasing resources as necessary to enable those Federal Police to be involved in the detection and disruption of people-smuggling activities. Those things are supportable, sustainable and not part of the so-called Pacific solution. In respect of each, Labor has a better plan than the current government for maintaining coastal surveillance and for policing in Indonesia.

Since the arrival of the Tampa, the government has had a scramble on to begin engaging with our region about people-smuggling issues. This has led to the Bali summit, which we heard about again today in question time. Labor believes that more could have been achieved had this regional engagement happened earlier. It is still a policy failure of some magnitude for this government that people-smuggling remains not a crime in Indonesia. Our capacity to deal with people smugglers is fundamentally undermined by the Howard government's failure to negotiate that simple change to Indonesian law.

The so-called Pacific solutionâstripped of the other policies that the government has scrambled around and tried to put in place since the Tampaâis really no more than the processing of people offshore in third countries. It is a policy that Labor does not support, because it achieves nothing and costs so much in so many waysâin money, in goodwill in our region and in division in our community. I would like briefly to take the House to the three principal problems with the so-called Pacific solution: costs, unsustainability and the fact that it delivers no outcomes.

I suspect that more has been written about the cost of the so-called Pacific solution than almost any other single topic in the last 12 months, but we still do not know the truth because the Howard government has not disclosed it. But we do know, courtesy of a leaked email that I have received from the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, that the department's annual appropriation has doubled over the life of the Howard government and now stands at a staggering $1.13 billion. Yet despite this astounding figure, on 5 August this year the acting secretary of the department emailed staff to inform them as follows:

quote.para: Some months ago, as part of the budget planning and review exercise, all divisions and state and territory offices were asked to develop detailed submissions of planning priorities and resource requirements for 2002-03 and beyond. The finance committee under my chairmanship met on 22 July 2002 to examine these submissions in the light of expenditure last year, forward estimates and new areas of pressure. We determined that, unless we took action, we were heading for a projected operating loss this year and in subsequent years of some $30 million per annum.

speech.para: So, despite an allocation of $1.13 billion, the department is heading for a loss of $30 million per annum. Surely we must say this is the so-called Pacific solution that bankrupted the department of immigration. We ask the government to come clean and say what is going to be cut: the compliance activities to catch illegal workers; the processing of family reunion applicationsâthe minister at the table, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, may have an interest in that in her capacity as a local memberâor the processing of skilled migration applications? What is going to be cut to fill in the $30 million black hole?

We know that the Pacific solution is unsustainable from the point of view of our agreements with Papua New Guinea and Nauru, with both of them stating substantial reservations about the continuance of the so-called Pacific solution. And we know that it delivers absolutely no outcomes, in that people are being resettled here from the so-called Pacific solution, despite this government's direct denials during the election campaign that that would happen. It is no wonder that they are herding these refugees onto Australian soil under cover of darknessâbecause they know how humiliating that is.

In the minute that remains to me, I will deal very briefly with the issue of children in detention, which was raised in question time today. Members opposite will get the opportunity to vote for Labor's amendment. It deals with getting unaccompanied children, as defined by the government's own laws, out of detention. So you cannot vote against it because it is a bad definitionâit is your definition. It also deals with getting accompanied children into a trial like the Woomera alternate detention trial. That is a trial evaluated by your own department as successful. I am going to be amazed to see on what basis you vote against it, if you do. (Time expired)

talker.name: Stone, Dr Sharman, MP
Dr STONE
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âI was listening to ABC Radio National last Saturday when a contributor lamented that no-one seemed to have a 20-year vision for rural and regional Australia. You would expect that sort of statement from someone like the member for Hasluck, whom we heard just a few speeches before lamenting our environmental credentials and mouthing the Labor Party policy. Anybody out there who has been remotely attuned to what has been going on with natural resource sustainability in this country would have understood that there has in fact been a revolution since 1996 in terms of the greatest investment this country has ever seen in natural resource management and in the way we are now dealing catchment by catchment and across landscapes to try to deliver sustainable natural resources. It is the first time the issue has been tackled across catchments in this country. It is the first time salinity has been tackled on a national basis. All of that is due, of course, to the change of government in 1996.

speech.para: So I listened to this observation on ABC radio, that there was no-one with a 20-year vision, and I thought I should put the record straight and talk about the concentrated refocus on the environment, social and physical infrastructure and the virtual revolution that has occurred throughout regional Australia since the first Howard government in 1996 when I and the member at the table, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, were first elected. Before 1996, for example, mobile phone coverage was a joke. Thousands of tiny telephone exchanges across the country were horse and buggy era and too antiquated to take modern communicationsâeven as basic a communication as a fax, much less high speed Internet access. Generations of country people had developed a culture of ignoring serious symptoms because doctors were so few in number and so overworked. It was all too long a wait and too hard to get an extended consultation to sort out anything other than the most mundane. If there were mental health issuesâperhaps depressionâand issues with complex symptoms, you simply put off that consultation, with the consequence of poorer health for rural and regional families.

Apprenticeships had fallen to an all-time low. In my region, additional qualified or apprentice plumbers, electricians, builders and boilermakersâall of them essential to the local economyâwere impossible to find. Employers were in despair because, without any protection from Labor's unfair dismissal laws, they knew that, if they did take a gamble with a new entrant to the work force, there was a possibility of them having to pay for having taken that gamble through some punitive action via a settlement out of court with an unfair dismissal case. They knew that it would be much smarter for them not to try to take on the new, untried person and perhaps set themselves up for a $7,000 or $8,000 payout, even if they were absolutely legitimate in what they did in terms of that unfair dismissal.

Federal highways like the Goulburn Valley carried bumper-to-bumper heavy transports loaded with export and domestic product, and they ducked and weaved along a single lane. In the winter of 1996âthe last time we had decent winter rainsâa number of local family members lost their lives as they waited in pouring rain to make a right-hand turn and were hit from the rear. Country people lost their lives on dangerously inadequate federal highways. Their fresh produce was invariably downgraded after its swinging, stop-start journey to the market. But it did not matter much at all what happened to the prime produce on the way to the port, since the time it took to load and send the containers on their way meant they were penalised anyway. Buyers knew Australian wharves were a cot case and they never expected any government would have the will or the gumption to break the stranglehold of the unions.

I could go on and on telling you how hard it was and why numbers of rural and regional people took to the politics of despair: the Pauline Hanson One Nation policies. These policies never offered solutions but articulated on their behalf the anger and frustration of a people who felt powerless and were locked into poverty trapsâremote, they feared, from the understanding or attention of policy makers in the Labor government. Let me tell you that, since the Howard government came into power, there has been a refocus on the infrastructure needs, the social policy and the taxation system policy necessary to give everyone a fairer go.

Consider the communications services. In my electorate alone, 42 exchanges were upgraded, and we now have virtually full mobile phone coverage. The Internet is everywhere, and it is fast and affordable. In the area of health, there is a department of rural health and a clinical school, which have brought medical and other health service students to town to train in the region, hopefully to stay. It is true that we have the lowest bulk-billing rates in the countryâdown to 37 per centâwhich means the poor and families still have to think twice about queuing in a GP's surgery, with the signs on the walls reminding them that they need to settle the $45 to $50 consultation fee before they leave. This government has done its best to speed up Medicare rebates by providing Easyclaim facilities, but it will take more doctors in the country to bring about the competition that will make a decision not to bulk-bill harder in the future. The government is addressing the channelling of new doctors into the system, ensuring that more of them are more likely to choose rural and regional practice in the future.

The Goulburn Valley Highway has now been duplicated, and the Roads to Recovery money is delivering dollars from the Commonwealth straight to local government. This money is seeing bridges rebuilt and bitumen put on roads that had not received attention for a generation, simply because there were not the dollars to go around.

We are a natural resource dependent economy. Over $14 million has been delivered in Murray alone by the NHT, with the NAP about to swing in. I want to talk about my particular vision for a change in landscape and a change in catchment management for the future, a change which is being ushered in by the innovative natural resource policies of this government. In the past, primary producers have depended on food and fibre production, and in a few cases wood production, to generate the income to keep their families. On private lands, that was the case. On public landsâthe national or state reserves and the parksâpersonnel are employed to make sure that these public lands were weed and feral animal free and to look after the natural resources.

We now have another way to deliver sustainable futures for rural communities without the loss of the population. Loss of population means fewer schools, hospitals, commercial centres and retail sectors of all types. I have a vision for private land in the future to be a patchwork of food, fibre, flour or timber production and the provision of ecosystem or environmental services, determined perhaps through a tender process. We have already trialled such a system. Environmental services may include feral animal and weed control, vegetation protection, fencing, habitat protection and rehabilitation. They could also extend to built heritage protection, where buildings were of a special significance to the nation's heritage.

As with the natural resource significance, the heritage significance would have to be something that the community as a wholeâthe nation as a wholeâsaw as worthy of public support. The Natural Heritage Trust funded bush tender was a 2001-02 trial of this ecosystem or environmental services alternative to traditional farming, and it has been highly successful. This bush tender called for land-holder interest in two Victorian designated areas between Bendigo and Ballarat and between Wangaratta and Wodonga. The aim was for land-holders to be paid to provide management servicesâecosystems servicesâon their properties to improve in particular important native vegetation. Farmers were asked to establish their own price for delivering these services, and then to submit a bid based on that price. The successful bids were those which offered best value for money. The payments came from the $1.5 billion Natural Heritage Trust funding, which in turn was achieved through the partial sale of Telstra. Needless to say, these ecosystem environmental services have been extraordinarily successful, and now the trial has been extended to Gippsland, where bids from land-holders are being called for this month.

This is the way we are now managing our Indigenous protected areas across the country. Aboriginal communities are delivering ecosystem or environmental services to protect their landscapes, often hugely degraded after a lot of pastoral overgrazing or feral animal and weed infestation. We support themâagain, through the Natural Heritage Trustâto work as land managers according to a special business plan. They have been enormously successful. We can look to their example to extend that same process across all of Australia where, in the future, private farm managers will have numbers of options. These will include food and fibre production and also ecosystem services delivery. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI bring to the attention of the House the plight of approximately 1,500 East Timorese nationals who have been seeking asylum in Australia since 1993. While the people of Australia well understand why we have mandatory detention for those people arriving in an Australian migration zone without entering through a designated port of entry, fair-minded Australians have viewed with utter dismay the plight of asylum seekers, who have suffered under the Howard government's cruel policy of prolonged detention, in particular, of women and children.

speech.para: On this side of the House, we are acutely aware of the concern of all Australians at this government's cynical agenda on certain elements of its immigration, refugee detention and border protection policies. Specifically, every day more and more Australians are questioning the lack of justice being meted out to many persons entering Australia, legally or otherwise, who seek Australia's protection from persecution of a prescribed kind under the United Nations convention and protocol for refugees. With help from some sections of the media, the government have portrayed the Bakhtiyari case as typical of most asylum seekers. This is simply not true and the government knows it.

The estimated 1,500 East Timorese asylum seekers who have waited quietly and patiently in Australia since 1993 hoping for asylum have been abandoned by the Howard government. No-one in this House can deny that, of all the people on this earth, the East Timorese deserved asylum from 1993 to the time of their vote for independence. The 1,500 East Timorese in Australia are not typical boat people seeking political asylum, as I have said. On 11 October 1995, the then shadow minister for foreign affairs and member for Mayo, the Hon. Alexander Downer, issued a media release entitled `East Timorese asylum seekers'. Mr Downer said:

quote.para: The claim made by Mr Paul Keating that `Timorese people have Portuguese citizenship' is wrong. Not one of the 1,300 East Timorese asylum seekers has applied for Portuguese citizenship. The fact is, Australia has never considered the people of East Timor as anything but Indonesian since 1979. This latest claim by Mr Keating that they are Portuguese is simply absurd and hypocritical.

speech.para: The member for Mayo repeated this attack in a further media release entitled `Senator Evans's hypocrisy over East Timorese asylum seekers', when he said:

quote.para: In the end, Gareth Evans's tortured logic has created a situation which is unsatisfactory to all three governments involved, to the applicants themselves and to the commonsense and fair play of Australians everywhere.

speech.para: The situation is that the 1,500 East Timorese asylum seekers have been denied protection by Australia since 1993âa period of nine years. I quote from a letter dated 15 May 1997, written by the then Archbishop of Sydney, Cardinal Edward Clancy, to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon. Philip Ruddock:

quote.para: I noted with interest the decision of the Full Bench of the Federal Court of Australia on Friday, 2 May 1997, (in the case of Jong Kim Ko v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs [1997] 306 FCA). It is my understanding that while the court found that the East Timorese have formal Portuguese nationality, any final decision on their status in Australia must also consider the effectiveness of this nationality.

speech.para: The issue is clearly whether Australia ever did owe such obligations to these estimated 1,500 East Timorese asylum seekers. It is now established by virtue of the Federal Court decision that Australia does owe such an obligation.

His Eminence Cardinal Clancy has also noted social segregation; family breakdown; the practical incapacity of those East Timorese to acquire Portuguese citizenship; social disruption, including alcohol and substance abuse; and the fact that some have married into Australian families since arriving here. So the question arises: why can't these East Timorese return to East Timor, following the holding of successful peaceful elections and the elimination of the immediate threat in their new found country? Why indeed can't they stay in Australia? The answer is that the sheer length of timeânine yearsâthat these people have been waiting in Australia has now permanently altered their lives. I am advised that many have now gone on to higher education and to job opportunities and are entrenched in life in Australia. Uprooting them would open a whole new world of disruption by returning them to a new country that is still struggling, in the aftermath of the devastation visited upon East Timor following the referendum for independence.

These people have suffered nine years of disruption to their livesâliving in Australia and waiting patiently for rights that they have never been allowed to enjoy. These rights have been denied by this government, which has sat on these applications, filed them away and done nothing with them. The immediate threat of violence has largely passed. Technically, these people can no longer claim protection under the United Nations convention and protocol for refugees. However, there is a prevailing injustice in light of the fact that this government has taken no action with these applications. The injustice most people feel is that these people have been compelled to remain in Australia so that their protection visa applications could be kept alive during the worst excesses of the violence in East Timor. In the meantime, they have sought to get on with their lives in Australia and to further themselves as best they can, always within an environment of uncertainty. Now, after nine years, these people have been compelled to return after becoming well settled in Australia and they thus face a further upheaval in their lives.

This situation is, to use the member for Mayo's own word, absurd. In rectifying this absurd situation, I call upon the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs to create a new subclass of visa that will permit this finite and discrete group of applicants the right to apply for permanent residency in Australia. Finally, in light of the totality of the suffering that these people have endured, it would be proper that Australia finally recognise the legitimate and comprehensive rights of these people from East Timor to remain permanently in Australia. To offer any less is unconscionable and unjust. These applicants have been denied their natural rights and I urge the government to honour those rights now.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on an issue of critical importance to my electorate. In doing so I will quote entirely from a paper that was compiled by Murrumbidgee Irrigation and that was delivered to the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council Community Advisory Committee. The reason I will quote entirely from this document is that I think it is an exact position of what we face with respect to the issue of how we access and deliver water into the future. The paper reads as follows:

quote.para: The issue of environmental flows and how to deliver a healthier river system for future generations presents significant challenges. How we go about that task, and how we apportion the costs and benefits may well determine success or failure.

Too often the debate about delivering healthier rivers has been conducted within a simplisticâand very destructiveâframework that equates environmental benefits with taking water off irrigators (and other current users). This equation polarises the community and shifts the policy debate and policy responses into the wrong areas. For instance, at present we are guilty of elevating one activityâwater recoveryâto an objective (which should be river health).

In reality, the Australian community, including irrigators, are being asked to consider investing in a healthier river. Such investments may include: infrastructure costs, research and development costs, the costs of ongoing management and operations of environment and other water, and the cost of reduced income from current water use. The benefits lie in improved natural assets that are available to all Australians.

At the outset we should therefore refocus attention away from `water recovery' and towards the environmental objectives of the proposal and sound planning principles. Only then will more strategies and activities make sense to stakeholders. Success may then depend on our ability, as a community, to design something that has equitable sharing of costs and benefits, and that meets objectives cost effectively. It is in this context that I want to highlight the three most important issues for Murrumbidgee Irrigation.

At present we are being asked to make judgments about the proposal to improve river health without the benefit of a comprehensive business plan to show that the use of resources is worthwhile and consistent with meeting objectives. Also, there is no mechanism that enables stakeholders to monitor and evaluate performance, and hold managers accountable.

As a business, Murrumbidgee Irrigation is responsible for the delivery of triple bottom-line outcomes in respect of finance, environment, and society. We acknowledge the importance of environmental objectives, and we invest in environmental outcomes, but we need sound business planning to satisfy ourselves, our shareholders, and our stakeholders that the use of resources is worthwhile and consistent with meeting our objectives. More especially, an agreed business plan enables our stakeholders to monitor our performance and hold us accountable for achievement of objectives.

The Company has also dealt with the planning needs associated with the recovery of environmental flows for the Murrumbidgee in 1999-2000. This requires revision of strategies and plans for marketing and managing the delivery of water for users, including: water pricing, management of flow rates, water transfer markets, investments in water saving, and the delivery of productivity gains from Company services.
As a member of the Australian community, what we do not know is how the water recovered for the environment has, or will, be used to deliver the potential environmental benefits.

To varying degrees, this inadequacy applies to much of our existing water management. But, the relative lack of management disciplines on environmental flows is of particular concern, if only because of the use of an adaptive approach to management.

The adaptive, `learning by doing', approach for management of environmental water may be the only sensible option given the present gaps in our knowledge. That said, we do know how to prepare a management plan. Indeed, the adaptive management approach only makes sense if there are very clear social contracts for the management of environmental water, very clear measures of performance, and mechanisms for accountability of managers. Without the latter, any adaptivity afforded our resource managers comes at very high risk.

The missing ingredient is a comprehensive river management plan, with ongoing planning processes. This planning system should start with water that is currently available to the environment, and have the following key elements:
. Clear statements of institutional arrangements for management of water, for use and for the environment, and of the roles and responsibilities of managers.
. Clear output intentions for environment water including priorities for action.
. Clear strategies for use of environment water, and other inputs, to deliver outputs.
. An annual `budget' for proposed environmental water activities.
. Comprehensive annual monitoring of results using established principles of water accounting (or water balances).
. Transparent and systematic annual reporting of performance to all stakeholders (that is subject to independent audit of performance).
