interjection.para: I have done the member for Lilley a disservice in that, as I had not heard his motion of suspension, I made a presumption that I ought not have made that it bore no relevance to the business currently before the House.

talk.start.para: âCan I finish my motion?

âThe member for Lilley may only entertain the motion if I have understood him in error. On the presumption that the motion to suspend standing orders does not deal with the business before the House, I will hear him at the conclusion of the business before the House.
âIt does, Mr Speaker.
âI am now extending a certain indulgence to the member for Lilley, as he must understand, to clarify the matter.

âCertainly. It does in this sense, Mr Speaker: my motion relates to events in the Main Committee which relate to an unresolved question as to confidence the Main Committee has in the chair of the Main Committee, and that relates directly to the operations of this House. As you would well remember, you and I have spoken about this, and I have been involved in this on other occasions. In that sense it does relate directly to the business in this Houseâ
âNo.

âbecause events in the Main Committee are not being conducted correctly. The Main Committee is a subcommittee and is subject to the standing orders of this House. We have an objection to the way in which business is being conducted in the Main Committee at this time; it reflects upon the status, standing and application of the standing orders in this main chamber of the House of Representatives.

âThe member for Lilley will be aware that he is drawing, by any measure, a very long bow. Nothing in the affairs currently being considered by the Main Committee has anything to do with the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2002 Budget Measures) Bill 2002.
âI am happy to call the member for Ryan, but does the member for Shortland have a point of order?
âNo.
âI am delighted to follow my friend and colleague the member for Curtin. I am delighted to speak in support ofâ

speech.para: Mr STEPHEN SMITH (Perth) (9.25 p.m.)âI move:

motion.para: That the member be not further heard.

speech.para: Question put.

talk.start.para: âI am delighted to speak in support of the government's Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2002 Budget Measures) Bill 2002â
âThe member for Ryan will resume his seat. The member for Perth, on a point of order.
âMr Speaker, pursuant to standing order 217A, I move:

motion.para: That the remaining stages of this bill be referred to the Main Committee for the second reading and consideration in detail stages.

speech.para: This is an appropriate bill to be referred to the Main Committee, unlike other bills which this government has sent to the Main Committee, trampling over people's consciences.

talk.start.para: âThe member for Perth will resume his seat.

interjection.para: Mr ABBOTT (WarringahâLeader of the House) (9.36 p.m.)âI move:

motion.para: That the member be not further heard.

interjection.para: Question put.

talk.start.para: âMr Speaker, I am seconding the motion of referral to the Main Committee.

âThe member for Lilley will resume his seat. Let me point out to members on my left that, to refer a matter to the Main Committee, it has to be at least seven days after the first readingâwhich would be the case in pointâand before the resumption of debate on the motion that this bill be now read a second time. The resumption of debate on the motion that this bill be now read a second time has already occurred. The next person with the call is the member for Shortland.

âMr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. My understanding of the argument being put about reference to the Main Committee is that the reference passed this afternoon overrides all of those procedural rules, which is precisely what we were arguing about in the first place.

âMy understanding is that the reference put this afternoon applied to the bills currently before the Main Committee, not the bills currently before the House, which is, of course, self-evident. The member for Shortland has the call.

interjection.para: Honourable members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI point out to members so anxious to offer the chair advice that, whatever they may or may not think about the fairness of the procedure, the member for Ryan's time has expired and so the call goes to the member for Shortland.

âMr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I moved, pursuant to standing order 217A, that the bill be referred to the Main Committee for the remainder of the second reading and consideration in detail stages. I was then gagged by the Leader of the House. At no point in any of that did the chair indicate to anyone that, in some manner or form, that motion was out of order. Standing order 217A makes it clear that that motion can be moved at any time. I have been gagged, the motion is entitled to be seconded, which the Manager of Opposition Business is proposing to do. That is the motion before the House.

âThe member for Perth knows that he is drawing an extremely long bow and testing the patience of the chair. In fact, the motion is out of order and that is why it cannot be seconded. As I have indicated, the motion currently before the chair is that this bill be now read a second time, and the bill being dealt with is the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2002 Budget Measures) Bill 2002.

âThank you, Mr Speaker. It really heartens me to hear how pleased members on the other side of the House are to see me rise to speak on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2002 Budget Measures) Bill 2002. I know they will be spending their entire time listening to my words and hanging off everything I have to say, because they know that we on this side of the House really care for veterans and have their interests at heart.

speech.para: This is important legislation that we on this side of the House support. This bill will enable the twice-yearly indexation of the ceiling rate of income support supplements and service pensions, and it really reflects the cost of living and the rises in wages that have taken place. The indexation of the war widows income supplement was frozen in 1986, and this change will allow the unfreezing of this allowance. In 1995, the income support supplement was created in the Veterans' Entitlements Act. At the same time, the frozen rate of $120.10 for war widows on an age pension came into being and many of those pensioners transferred from Centrelink to DVA.

I believe that members in this House will join in support of this bill. It really looks at budget measures. There is only one key issue, and that is the amendment that provides for the indexation of the income supplement for war widows which we are supporting without hesitation. Every member of this House appreciates the contributions that veterans have made to our country. I think it is only fitting that we should remember that when debating this legislation. In doing so, we have to pay tribute to war widows and the support that they have given to their veteran partners and spouses over the years. It has been a long time coming, but it is good that this allowance is now going to be unfrozen. The war widows pension, as we all know, is a lifetime tax-free benefit, and when these changes come into place it will operate in a way that benefits the war widows.

Whilst discussing this legislation, I would like to bring to the attention of the House a ceremony that I attended last Sunday at Swansea, which is within the electorate of Shortland. It was the rededication of the Swansea community war memorial, and it had enormous support from the community. This rededication of the memorial was necessary because the community had joined with the Swansea RSL subbranch and the Swansea RSL and built a wonderful new memorial as a tribute to the veterans of our community.

The thing that is so special about this memorial is the inclusion of water in the monument. It is a beautiful marble monument with a water theme. When we look at the service that our veterans have performed over the years, and the connection of this particular area with the water, it makes for a spectacular monument to our veterans. I need to bring to the House's attention the enormous support of the community and the many people who contributed to the cost of the reconstruction and rededication of this community war memorial. We had Brian Arkell, who is a local solicitor, Barry's Quality Pies, Blacksmiths Home Hardware, Cardiff RSL Subbranch and Catherine Hill Bay RSL Subbranch. Catherine Hill Bay is a very tiny place with only about 200 people in the community, but that RSL subbranch contributed towards this wonderful memorial. We have S.P. Chapman optometrists, the City of Newcastle RSL Subbranch, Bruce Clancy, C.D. and S.Y. Colhoun, B. Cunningham, Dorothy's Skin Clinic, Jim Durie, D. and J. Evans, Civic Videos and the Hadfield family. Carrol Hall, who is a real estate agent and no relation to me, contributed as well. I made a contribution, as did Islington RSL Subbranch and Kim Mangos, the local physiotherapist. The maritime services union made a contribution, along with the Newcastle RSL District Council, Newcastle Permanent Building Society, our state member Milton Orkopoulos, Parsons Funerals, N.R. Peattie, Pelican Flats RSL Club, which is the adjoining subbranch, Ken Rutledge Roofing, Shortland RSL Subbranch, Ann and Alan Smith and R.A.J. Stamm. Swansea RSL Club made a substantial donation, as did Swansea Workers' Club. The Department of Veterans' Affairs supported the new memorial. They could see that it was really needed in the area. Also, Newcastle Vietnam Veterans' Association, Wallsend RSL Subbranch and Arthur Woods contributed. I read all those names out to show you the support in the community for this memorial and for veterans. Any legislation that is introduced into this House that helps veterans and war widows is welcomed by the community as a whole.

One of the things that has been of great concern to me and to the veterans in the community I represent is the gold card. There have been a number of issues around the gold card within my electorate recently. Doctors have started lobbying for increased fees for the treatment of veterans under the Repatriation Private Patients Scheme. I am sure that I am not the only member in this House who has been contacted by veterans in our electorates. With the gold card, as we all know, veterans are able to access free treatment from their doctors. Recently, veterans have been finding, when they go to the doctor, that the doctor refuses to accept their gold card in payment of services. It has happened with general practitioners and with specialists.

talk.start.para: âName one!

âMany doctors are refusing to look after our veterans who went to war, who supported our country and have been prepared to give their lives for our country. The issue of spiralling medical indemnity insurance premiums has added significantly to health costs and has also led to an increase in the price that veterans have to pay for their visits to the doctor, as is the case with all people in the community.

speech.para: While I am not prepared to name a doctor who is not bulk-billing veterans, what I will share with the House is a survey that I performed in the electorate. I rang 25 doctors, randomly chosen, and asked them whether or not they were bulk-billing pensioners and whether they were accepting the gold card from veterans. I found a very sad state of affairs. Over 20 per cent of the doctors I contacted said that they were no longer bulk-billing veterans. Twenty per cent of the doctors said that the men who went overseas and fought for our country were no longer going to have their gold cardâwhich was given to them when they came back at the end of the warâhonoured. They were no longer going to receive the free medical treatment that they had been promised. The doctors have been lobbying the government and the government has done nothing to resolve this matter.

With the issue of medical indemnity insurance and the government's failure to resolve that problem, we find that there is an enormous increase in consultation fees being charged by doctors. One practice within my electorate has recently, since this problem with the medical indemnity insurance arose, increased its fees from $38 to $43 to $47. When a veteran believes that their gold card is going to be accepted to pay for their medical treatment and they are denied that, they are faced with having to pay a bill of $47. That is not good enough, and that is not what we promised our veterans. Similarly, another surgery has increased its fees from $37 to $40, and so it goes on.

I believe that our veterans deserve better than they are getting from this government. They expect more and, to be quite honest, I expect more. Those doctors I surveyed were in the Lake Macquarie part of the Shortland electorate. We are also receiving phone calls from the Central Coast. I have had two phone calls and an email today in relation to the fact that doctors are not accepting the gold card. The AMA have written to all members of this parliament about this matter and how they need the government to act immediately. If they do not act immediately, we are going to have the same situation that we have with bulk-billing generally and those veterans who have looked to the government for security, those veterans who have fought for our country, will be let down and will be forced to pay for a service that they have always believed was their right to receive.

Another budget measure that was introduced this year that had the potential to cause enormous hardship to veterans was the increase in pharmaceuticals. I am pleased to see that has been stalled in the Senate, but I feel sure that this government will bring it back and try to bring about that increase. There is no group of people in the community who are more reliant on medication than our veterans. I have recently been approached by quite a few veterans who are upset about some of the medication that is no longer covered by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. They are also very worried about what the effect will be of this increase in cost that the government is still trying to push through. One veteran I was talking to told me that he takes 18 tablets a day. He is terrified about the proposed increase in the cost of medicines, as is another veteran who takes 14 tablets a day. Another veteran that has been coming along to talk to me recently is also quite upset about the cost that he incurs in having his medication packed in a Webster pack. What the government has done with that particular budget measure is try to introduce a quick-fix approach rather than looking at all the issues that surround the cost of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

For the remainder of my speech I would like to refer to a submission that the Partners of Veterans Association of Australia Inc. have submitted to the Committee for Review of Veterans' Entitlements. This is a particularly strong group of women. Their patron is Mrs Lynne Cosgrove. Their president is Narelle Bromhead, who lives within the Shortland electorate. The women who are involved in this group are very dedicated. They are dedicated to improving conditions for veterans and their partners. In their submission they start off by reaffirming their unreserved commitment to the veterans of the Australian armed forces with qualifying service and then go on to talk about a number of issues. They talk about the war widows compensation pension. This pension was introduced under the War Pensions Act 1914 as compensation, paid to veterans' widows, for the death, from war related injuries, of their husbands. The submission refers to a speech that was made in 1917 by the then defence minister, Senator Pearce. The speech reads:

quote.para: One of the saddest spectacles of the past has been to see men who have been willing to risk their lives in the defence of their country left destitute and the dependants of men who have laid down their lives for their country having to live on charity.

speech.para: That is a situation that these women worry about. They feel that, currently, they are not adequately covered and that there are quite a few problems in this act, particularly in relation to younger war widows. They make the point:

quote.para: The Australian government must consider as a first priority, veterans of the Australian forces with `qualifying service' and their dependent families.

speech.para: They say that they welcome the changes in this legislation but they believe that it does not go far enough.

They refer to the war widows compensation payment, the domestic allowance that is paid to war widows, and the income support supplement and the need to revisit that. In particular, they refer to the issue of age. The income support supplement is payable to women over 58, and they refer to the impact that has on younger women. This group of women are particularly concerned about the fact that younger widows are expected to try to re-enter the work force but they are not given adequate training to do that. They do not believe that the government is really serious about supporting war widows and helping them re-enter the work force or to develop new skills. They see that a lot of war widows have been under extreme pressure for a considerable time and they view it as a cost-cutting exercise rather than an exercise designed to help them. I call on the government to really get serious about veterans and to support our veterans and our war widows. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)âBefore I call the member for Hasluck, I remind the member for Shortland that contributions to a debate should be relevant to the bill before the House. I ask the member for Shortland to take that into consideration in future debates.

âI rise to speak on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2002 Budget Measures) Bill 2002 and the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002. I am always pleased to have the opportunity to speak on legislation that affects veterans. This is especially so because it gives me the opportunity to pay tribute to them and to acknowledge their service to the country. I was privileged, as an official of the Miscellaneous Workers Union, to meet many veterans employed as national park rangers, security officers and in other industries covered by the union. Often these menâand I think it is a reflection of their character and who they areâalso volunteered to take on roles such as delegates in their workplace, taking on the responsibility of representing their fellow workers and taking up issues on their behalf with the employer. Such workplace representatives make an extraordinary contribution to their colleagues. In particular, I am talking about people such as Cedric Turnerâor `Shorty', as we know himâColin Evans and Ron Donnelly, who were all rangers at Kings Park; Bob Woods, who continues to play an extremely active role in the TPI Association; Roy Harris, the national park ranger; Brian Nealâor `Bulk', as we know him; Warren South; Phil Kaye, a long-serving representative at CSBP; and of course Phil Clover, who is vice president of the union's Western Australian branch. Given earlier discussion in the House today concerning the Kokoda Track, the House may be pleased to know that Phil has made a significant contribution to following the track and finding the various battlegrounds that have recently been commemorated by the Prime Minister on his trip to Papua New Guinea.

speech.para: As I said, these men continued to serve the community in many capacities after returning from active duty, and their selfless concern for their fellows is heartwarming. That is why it is with great sadness that I have seen some of these men suffer the health consequences of their service to the country. Despite the good services of the Western Australian office of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, it has often been a difficult time for them and their families. I continue to wish them all well and offer what support I can as they deal with those issues.

I would also like to take this opportunity to congratulate the Minister for Veterans' Affairs for the issuance of the new certificates of appreciation under the Saluting their Service program. It is particularly pleasing to me that these certificates will also recognise what I call the newer veteransâthat is, those people returning from service or who served in the Gulf War and in various peacekeeping operations. I am glad they will have their contributions recognised early, unlike the struggle that existed for those Vietnam veterans who were shamefully ignored for many years. However, I do not share the minister's concern in her press release that one of the reasons that we need to do this is that, because of the ageing of our veterans, somehow in the future there will be less attention or recognition paid to Anzac Day. I am pleased to say that I attended many Anzac services in my community and was astounded by the number of young people in particular who proudly wore medals and the like from uncles and grandfathers. Also, nearly all the schools in my electorate had some service to commemorate Anzac Day.

I will now go to the specifics of the legislation. The first of these two bills seeks to make three amendments to address inequities and anomalies with regard to the war widows income support supplement, the third being a drafting correction. Amendments in the second bill serve mainly as minor legislative housekeeping items. The first bill aims to remove the frozen ceiling rate of the income support supplement, which is paid to recipients of the war widows and widowers pension, and to twice yearly index the rate proportionally both to CPI and average male weekly earnings in line with other main income support pensions. The amendments also propose concurrent backdating for three months prior to the date of the claim for income support supplement, in line with the present war widows and widowers pension. This will alleviate the financial disadvantage that arises when social security payments cease on granting of the war widows and widowers pension. As it currently stands, the payment of the income support supplement can be provided only from the date of the claim.

Although it is encouraging to see some of the anomalies and inequities in the legislation being addressedâfor which I offer my supportâthere still exists a situation under the proposed amendments whereby a war widow or widower under the age of 57, and who is without children, cannot get income support supplement, nor can they get the disability support pension.

The government has failed to support the war widows and widowers, who may find themselves in this situation, essentially leaving them with no more than the war widowers pension should their partners die. There could very well be situations where a widow or widower may have spent much of their time as a carer for their veteran partner, often dealing with all of the health care problems of their spouse and the stress that that causes their family. It seems to me that they may find that this has kept them from being able to actively participate in the work force for many years and, of course, they will find it very difficult to find immediately new employment. As the legislation currently stands, widows and widowers in this position seem to me to be almost forgotten and simply left to deal with the system irrespective of the service and the contribution that their spouse has made. I think this shows that there are still a number of issues confronting veterans and their families that the government needs to address. These are some of the areas I want to touch on tonight.

The first of them is that the government is still failing to live up to its promise to remove the disability pension from the means test at Centrelink. Currently, veterans with disabilities caused by their service have up to $157 per fortnight deducted from their disability support pension, due to the inclusion of their veteran disability pension in the DSP means test. This situation could be further worsened by any move by the government to force veterans who are currently on the disability support pension to the Newstart allowance. Not only is the Newstart allowance $52 per fortnight less than the DSP but the means test for the Newstart allowance is also much tougher, with the income fee reduced from $112 to $62. For veterans in this position, the exclusion of their non-taxable, non-means tested DVA disability pension from the Centrelink means test would result in immediate and substantial financial relief. This policy suggests that payments of compensation which are made for pain and suffering, albeit unfairly, count as income only for ex-service people and not for the rest of the communityâthat exclusion is good enough for the wider community but not good enough for veterans. The discriminatory legislation needs to be amended, and with a far greater sense of urgency than this government appears to be prepared to commit. The time has come for the government to stop ignoring the obvious inequities in the legislation and to stop placing the burden for its mismanagement on those men and women who have served this country.

The member for Shortland addressed what appears to be recent evidence from members in this House which exposes a trend of gold cards being rejected by some doctors when veterans present for medical treatment. This is also a slap in the face for veterans. We are told that many doctors claim that the schedule feesâthat is, the Commonwealth medical benefits scheme ratesâare now below the actual cost of providing some services. The government is fully aware of the problem and seems to me to be refusing to address the issue. Instead, veterans are likely to be made to seek medical treatment as general patients and to pay the gap between the Medicare rebate and the fee being charged by doctors. If we are not careful, the gold card is at serious risk of becoming redundant as once again this government ignores the needs of veterans and their families. Veterans deserve to have free access to health care, especially in their older years or if they are suffering from service related injuries. They are entitled to the free treatment that they have been promised. That is part of the deal we do with them when they make their commitment to serve the country.

This government has stalled other reforms with respect to veterans' issues. The Clarke review of veterans' entitlementsâwith, I suggest, its misguided terms of referenceâis a classic example of how the government is successfully delaying or putting on ice areas in the Veterans' Entitlements Act that need urgent attention, such as those that fail to adequately recognise the level of service carried out by the SAS. It is also an admission of a failed government policy for veterans. The SAS is not just an elite Defence Force unit; it is a unit whose members are highly trained and skilled at working in the most arduous and stressful conditions. The risk of injury or illness from such service is without question very high, as those serving and their families well know. In order to attain such an elite level, SAS personnel must undergo hazardous training and be exposed to situations of extremely high risk. Exposure to this level of training must be more adequately recognised, and an inquiry should be considered to determine the long-term effects of such service.

I know a little about this area, as another veteran I admireâa man named Rick Giblettâhas been campaigning for many years to gain proper recognition for service personnel involved in counter-terrorist training. The three things that he has vigorously pursued include, firstly, that counter-terrorist training be declared as hazardous service, to ensure that SAS personnel are able to get access to entitlements under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. Secondly, there is the question of access to and the level of TPI entitlements and other compensation, as well as the issue of how Centrelink treats these payments. I am aware that these two issues are now part of the current review. I join with veterans and veterans' supporters in my electorate of Hasluck in hoping for a speedy resolution and a successful outcome which clearly recognises that counter-terrorist training is hazardous service and that those personnel involved should be properly treated.

The third thing which Rick Giblett and his organisation have been campaigning forâand which I wish to speak aboutâis a health study. This would be an opportunity to put in place a proper and considered study which collects the facts concerning the health of these particular veterans or personnel. This would acknowledge what those of us who deal with veterans know for a factâthat is, the health issues and problems that these people are dealing with now. Hopefully, the study will make proper recommendations for the future.

It was my intention when I first drafted this speech to have quite a go at the Minister for Veterans' Affairs for her failure to take up this question. It seemed to me to be absolutely outrageous that you would have to campaign to get someone to look into whether or not a problem existed amongst this dedicated force. I have been advised very recently by some of the people who are in discussions with the Department of Veterans' Affairsâand I might say that the negotiations with the department seem to be much more successful than those that have been held with the minister and her representativesâthat at least those senior people appear now to recognise the great need for an inquiry to be undertaken. I hope that that is the case. I commend them if that is the case. If it is not, I will be back on my feet in this place to make quite a song and dance about it. I have had the opportunity to meet not only with Rick but also with others and to hear first-hand the story of many of the people who have been involved with the SAS and with counter-terrorist training. How anyone could suggest that they do not have a legitimate claim is absolutely beyond me.

Perhaps I can put the minister on notice in that respect: she will have my congratulations if the health study is announced and she will hear from me againâand, I am sure, from many othersâif it is not. In relation to that, I particularly commend those veterans and representatives of veterans' organisations who have been involved with that active campaign and have been lobbying for what must be at least five years to see this finally come to fruition. I convey my regret that this parliament and this government did not choose to act earlier on this particular issue.

Earlier I commented on the Clarke review and voiced my concern about some of the terms of reference for the review. I did that because I think the review has failed to address a number of the issues that confront the totally and permanently incapacitated, TPI, group of veterans. This group has been lobbying the government without success for the last few years to address the shortfall in the value of the special rate they receive as formulated all those years ago. Frankly, that rate has been considerably eroded since. It should also be noted that many TPI veteransâthat is, veterans who are considered incapable of working more than eight hours a week because of injuries incurred in the service of this countryâalso fall into the group that are affected by the inclusion of their disability pensioners income in the Centrelink means test, further eroding what might be considered a reasonable standard of living.

In relation to that, I take this opportunity to acknowledge the tireless work and efforts of the many veterans and veterans' organisations I have had the privilege to be involved with since becoming a member of parliament. Tireless campaigners for veterans' rights such as Brian Reeks, a veteran from Thornlie in my own electorate, keep me well informedâon a daily basis, on some occasionsâof the many issues confronting veterans, and in particular those issues facing TPI veterans. Brian, along with the Australian Federation of Totally and Permanently Incapacitated Ex-Servicemen and Women, WA Branch, has lobbied and continues to lobby government on behalf of this group of veterans. They should be commended for their efforts. In that regard, I earlier referred to Bob Woods, another good friend and a solid campaigner in the Active TPI Association. The association have been very active in my home state of Western Australia, attempting to bring their issues to the attention of the community. I have to say that the community of Western Australia supports them wholeheartedly. It is, I think, time that this government addressed the situation of these people in a considered way.

Whilst I am paying tribute to those organisations which lobby on behalf of veterans, I absolutely cannot forget the returned servicemen's leagues in my electorate of Hasluck which also do a great job in serving both the returned veterans and the wider community. In particular, I refer to the Bellevue RSL, the Darling Range RSL and the Gosnells RSL, which are all active groups. Along with their respective sub-branch women's auxiliaries groups, they work tirelessly for their respective local veterans' communities and their families. I feel it is vitally important to recognise their efforts. In an age where volunteer organisations are struggling to maintain an operable level of membership, the RSLs in Hasluck stand out as shining examples of how this can be achieved. I offer them my best wishesâand long may they rule! In fact, a couple of those RSL associations are some of the many groups that ensure that there are well-attended services each year, particularly on Anzac Day but also on other important days of recognition, such as Sunday, 18 August for the Vietnam veterans community. I am sure that these services and the work these organisations do in the community will ensure not only that the issues of veterans are brought to the fore but also that we continue to respect and honour the service that has been given to the country by those veterans and their organisations.

One particularly heart-warming ceremony I attended on Anzac Day was held at the Railway Workshops, Midland. They have what is known as a peace memorial rather than a war memorial. Funds were raised by the workers in the workshops back in 1923 to build the memorial. They raised 1,000, which in those days was a considerable amount of money. The names not only of those workers who lost their lives in World War I but also of those who lost their lives in World War II are duly recorded on the peace memorial. It is a magnificent memorial: it is a woman standing with her left foot on a sword and with her right arm extended, simply asking for war to cease. It was delightful to see the memorial and to see the relatives, including the grandchildren, of those workshop personnel there. I commend the bills to the House. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âOrder! Given the flexibility that the member for Fraser has already commended in the chair's actions at adjournment earlier this day, it might be appropriate if, even at this early hour, I were to put the question. It being 10.28 p.m., I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to inform the House of a growing problem in the electorate of Greenway. This is a problem that I believe could easily be rectified by this government, but they choose not to do anything. The problem was highlighted in a couple of questions from the opposition at question time today. The problem I am talking about is the severe lack of child-care places available to the mums and dads in my electorate.

speech.para: Greenway is located in one of the fastest growing areas of New South Wales. New housing developments and the attractive lifestyle of living in a great part of Sydney are bringing many young families to the area. Between 1996 and 2001 the population of Blacktown grew by over 26,250 people, which was the second largest increase in New South Wales. A huge increase in population like that naturally places a large burden on the local child-care centres, where the waiting lists are growing and families are getting frustrated. The child-care centres themselves are being frustrated, because they wish to expand and accommodate new families. They know how tough it is and they want to do something to help, but they are unable to because of a regime that does not allow the flexibility that is needed in an area like mine.

In a question without notice by the member for Gellibrand today, it was shown that, since the government came to power in 1996, spending on child care has fallen by over $800 per child-care place, placing a huge strain on providers, who are forced to cut costs wherever they can. There is a particular problem in my electorate with OOSH services, out of school hours services, because the regime that governs the number of places is particularly rigid. Areas like Glenwood, Quakers Hill, Marayong and Schofields are in desperate need of more places, but these places are unavailable. These services have to wait until a committee of bureaucrats politely ask each OOSH in other areas if they will give up some of the places that they are not currently using. Not too many services have spare places to give up, and those that do are naturally unwilling to do so in case of future demand. This leaves the growing areas out in the cold.

One case in point is the South Marayong out of school hours care service at Marayong South Public School. SMOOSH, as it is called, began its service in January 2001 with 30 places both before and after school. In the last 12 months they have seen their attendance grow from 2,788 hours of care in term 2 2001 to 6,306 hours of care in term 2 2002. That is a 150 per cent increase in just 12 months. They have a growing waiting list for next year. Honourable members can see by this growth that they are desperately in need of more places, but there are simply none to be had.

I have also received a letter from the operators of Schofields OOSH. They are also struggling with numbers and facing huge residential developments over the next few years. Glenwood and Stanhope Gardens are, similarly, crying out for more places. Even if parents were willing to pay full costs, without government subsidies, these OOSH services would be unable to help given the restrictions of the legislation, which does not allow subsidised and non-subsidised places at the same centre.

It is fine for universities to have full fee paying students sit next to HECS place students in the same class as a way of expanding opportunities in that sector, but it is not okay for the same arrangement to take place at an outside school hours care centre. This is a piece of logic that escapes me. I have been contacted by many constituents who have been to a number of child-care centres in the area, none of which can take their children because they are full to the brim already. Greenway is a growing area and the growth shows no signs of slowing down, with new housing developments planned for many parts of the electorate and a move in the older areas to medium density housing. With house prices the way they are, young families often need a second income that requires both parents to be working.

Children need to be looked after and our child-care system needs to be flexible enough to meet the needs of a rapidly growing community. Unfortunately, what I see is a rigid and inflexible system that struggles to keep up with the changing needs of a growing community. This is precisely why the government must step in and act. Only the government can provide the legislative and financial framework for the overall system. All the framework needs is re-examination and adjustment from time to time, and the time has come for the child-care system. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe questionâon which, it is fair to say, I have been interrupted in another placeâof when does life begin has given rise to some significant and difficult differences. For the purposes of this debate tonight, there are four views which I wish to raise. The first is what I am going to call the farm view. This is perhaps the most commercial of all the views. It holds that life only begins at birth, because the foetus has independent existence. But, if independence is the test, even the child is not human until it can survive on its own. Some have suggested that, if independence is the test of human life, independence may not occur until children reach teenage years or even until they leave home.

speech.para: The second view is what I call the `ensoulment' view, which perhaps has been best expressed by St Augustine many hundreds of years ago. This view states that it is at 46 days after the fertilisation of the eggâwhen the soul first enters the foetus, making it appear to move or quickenâthat human life first begins. The difficulties with this approach are that it appears to be arbitraryâwhy not 66 days? Why not 275 days?âand that some do not accept that the soul exists or is a sign or emblem of humanity. I should add that that view has been referred to by leaders in the Uniting Church as being the appropriate view.

A third view is that it is only 14 days after conception, when the blastocyst attaches to the uterine wall or is implanted, that it can be said that some form of human life exists. This has been the view expressed by, amongst others, Archbishop Carnley, the primate of the Anglican Church, and by several advisers to Pope Paul VI at the time of the writing of the Humanae Vitae in 1972. The difficulty with this approach is that some scientists have suggested that this process can occur prior to 14 days, and why, one might ask, is dependence on the mother rather than existence of the embryo the relevant test. The fourth view which has gained currency is the moment of conception, which until recently has been considered to be the moment of fertilisation, when the sperm gametes penetrate the egg gametes. But why is it not the creation of the sperm in the genitalia of the man when life truly begins, as argued by Aristotleâthe egg merely being the source of sustenance or a vehicle for the sperm to achieve human form? Why is it not at the formation of the limited supply of eggs in a young woman?

This discussion illustrates that there are problems with every view as to the real commencement of human life. Each view has some truth, or tells some truth about humanity which is an important aspect of our humanity. Vulnerability is characteristic of each stage. The review suggests that any curtailment of human life, at any stage, is unfortunate and that our focus should be on saving life as a means of protecting it. Hence it can rationally be argued that where life can sustain lifeâthat is, where the embryo can be used to sustain another life by curing some incurable or life-threatening diseaseâthe purpose of life indeed has been fulfilled. Thus the argument is not about destroying human life but about sustaining it by the use of the embryo to produce a stem cell that will, upon adaptation, save or improve an existing life. The moral competition is not between the two precepts `Thou shalt not kill' and `Thou shalt love thy neighbour' but rather the dominance of the latter over the former. The question is important because it will rise again in future debates about human life and medicine, as science becomes more sophisticated and remedies for disease are found that are even more radical than those contemplated by the stem cell debate.

I wish to concentrate on an even more precise question than the one I posed in relation to the moral debate. The pressing question is: when precisely does the embryo have accorded to it the status of an individual human person or potential person for whom basic rights of care, protection and life may be claimed? The theological principle behind medical ethics is that all human life is sacred, and on this all Christians and those from many other religions will agree. However, it was in 1869 that, for the Western world at least, the general question was first enunciated by Pope Paul IX. It was then stated that the moment of conception was the relevant point in time. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise this evening to bring to the attention of the House an exciting environmental restoration project undertaken by year 11 students from Toronto High School in my electorate of Charlton. The project seeks to restore a degraded stream bank on Stony Creek, which is an important estuary that runs into Lake Macquarie. Such has been the excellence of the work that the project is to be recognised internationally by the Volvo Young Environmentalist Awards. Year 11 students Chris McLean, David Carrall and Tony Owen, who have planned and coordinated the restoration project together with biology teacher Greg Smith, will travel to Gothenburg in Sweden next month to be presented with this prestigious international award. These students planned and are currently implementing the project, which has involved a large amount of time in preparing, researching and training to ensure its success.

speech.para: I understand that these students have spent many hours reading through Lake Macquarie City Council stormwater and estuary management reports. They have had to determine the range and prevalence of different species living in the creek's ecosystem through on-site analysis and by consulting experts for positive identification of certain species. Training in weed removal and in occupational health and safety has also been undertaken by the students. The project to restore the banks of Stony Creek has been quite involved. It has included the time-consuming process of replanting eroded areas with specially selected salt tolerant plants. These plants will assist in stabilising the creek's banks. Whilst a number of the plants being used have been provided by the company Trees In Newcastle, many others are being propagated by the students from collected seeds. A nursery is currently under construction by Toronto High School students and other community volunteers under the supervision of Chris, David and Tony, which will consist of around 1,500 plants and 1,000 square metres of mulched native gardens. Funds for the nursery have been provided by the school and Lake Macquarie City Council. The nursery will provide an important riparian buffer between the school and the creek. The stream bank buffer is needed to limit run-off between the school and creek, to slow water movement and to filter nutrients that may otherwise enter the estuary.

Chris, David and Tony have also proved to be very effective communicators of their plans and ideas and of the progress of the project. Part of the reason they were successful in achieving this significant international award is the manner in which they have kept the community aware of the project. There have been many dealings with the press which have highlighted their achievements and aims through events such as World Environment Day, Biodiversity Week, National Tree Day and Landcare Week. The Newcastle and Lake Macquarie media have provided coverage through newspaper articles, television news stories and radio. The immediate community would also be aware of the project through stencilled signs on drains in the area marked `The creek starts here'. The students have also engaged in liaison with the wider community by taking tours of Landcare group members to the site of the restoration work and hosting students from the school and its feeder primary schools to participate in environmental awareness activities. Chris, David and Tony will be attending a Rotary dinner to present their project to local Rotarians. I will be honoured to attend the school next week to tour the site and speak with Toronto High School students and staff about this very exciting project and the presentation of the award in Sweden.

This entire project is yet another impressive example of the invaluable contributions young people make to our community. Whilst it is fantastic that Chris, David and Tony have received such prestigious recognition, there are still many young people who do not receive the recognition they deserve. Many young people are involved in volunteer organisations contributing to their local, national and international communities and providing services and support in a wide range of areas to further the aims and ideals of our community. This entire project has provided an exciting learning experience for Toronto High School students and is an example of how learning in our schools can change from the old model of kids cooped up in classrooms being told what they must know for their exams. Practical, hands-on learning inspires students who may otherwise not be so interested or capable learners. As the old Chinese proverb says, `Tell me, and I'll forget. Show me, and I may remember. Involve me, and I'll understand.' I commend the students of Toronto High School and wish Chris McLean, David Carrall, Tony Owen and their teacher, Greg Smith, all the best for their trip to Sweden for the presentation of the Volvo Young Environmentalists Award. I am sure they will continue to succeed in their pursuit of improved environmental outcomes for Lake Macquarie and the important estuary of Stony Creek.

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight with great pride to speak of the students and teachers at the Myrrhee Primary School in my electorate. It is a small government school located in the picturesque wine and tobacco region of the King Valley. It is my pleasure to bring to the House's attention the spectacular achievements of the school's staff and students in the Education Foundation's Dreams and Schemes Awards. What makes the achievements of Myrrhee Primary School so special is not only that they are a small school of 31 students and not only that grade 4 entered these awards in the grade 5 and 6 category but also that they won four out of the five awards in that category. I strongly suspect that they would have made a clean sweep of all the awards had they actually submitted a further entry.

speech.para: The Dreams and Schemes Awards recognise and encourage students as inventors and identify innovations that can potentially be applied in the community at large. The top award won by the school is the 2002 Super Science School Award for their outstanding performance and participation in these awards. Joint winners of the best individual energy idea are Myrrhee Primary School students Georgina Long and Blake Sheather. Georgina's invention is the `Doggie Come Home', a dog collar device activated by a mobile phone. Georgina's dream for her idea is that through the invention of this collar there will not be as many stray dogs, which would be of benefit not only to dog owners and the public but also to the environment. Blake's concept of a vineyard `Bird Scarer' addressed the current problem that birds have become accustomed to timer-activated scare guns. His invention is a loudspeaker automatically activated by birds. The loudspeaker would produce a range of sound effects that frighten birds away from ripening vineyards. This invention would not only be of particular value to award-winning wineries like Dal Zottos and Pizzini's in Blake's backyard but also be useful to the many wineries in Indi. It is important to note that Blake's invention also won the award for the most outstanding innovative idea.

Student Ronan Border won the award for the best individual environment idea, a `Watch Watch', a wristwatch that can serve to act both as a screen and a remote control for security cameras in vineyards, clearly an idea with potential to be applied to the general security of commercial premises. Jessica Graham won the award for the best individual biology-chemistry idea, with the `Marc Pot', a biodegradable pot made from wine industry waste that would reduce the number of plastic pots that would eventually end up in landfills.

Perhaps by necessity, perhaps by history, country people have always been innovative and self-reliant, both individually and collectively. The students of Myrrhee Primary School are evidence that the spirit of innovation is alive and well in north-east Victoria. These students have the skills, confidence and ability to make a significant contribution not only to their local community but to Australia. They have a great future ahead of them and I am very proud of them. I have no doubt that with the continued support of their parents and the inspiration and guidance from the staff at the Myrrhee Primary Schoolâthe principal, Geoff Lacey, teacher Diane Morrison and administrative aide Robyn Kilgourâthe students of this local north-east primary school will have every chance to fulfil the potential they obviously have.

talk.start.para: âDuring the grievance debate earlier today the member for Paterson accused me of both lying and misleading the House. Through you, Mr Speaker, I thank Deputy Speaker Causley for insisting that the member for Paterson withdraw those unsubstantiated remarks. It was an ill-conceived attack because in fact I accused the member for Paterson of nothing. Rather, I shared with the House a number of stories which have been relayed to me by a number of concerned citizens in the Hunter community. Those stories revolved around the member for Paterson's alleged role in the sacking of the Chairman of the Hunter Area Consultative Committee.

speech.para: Allegedly, the member for Paterson had sought the assistance of Mr Humphrey in securing a Dairy RAP grant for his mate and businessman Joe Sepos. When Mr Humphrey refused to short cut the process, the member for Paterson embarked on a campaign of retribution, working against Mr Humphrey in his attempt to become the endorsed Liberal candidate in the state seat of Maitland and having him sacked as Chairman of the Hunter Area Consultative Committee. The member for Paterson's preferred candidate is Mr Bob Geoghegan. As I said last Thursday night, Mr Geoghegan and the member for Paterson go back some time. The member for Paterson has since claimed that he did not know Mr Geoghegan before entering into a lease with him for his electorate office before 1998, but I know with absolute confidence that there is no shortage of people in the Maitland area who would testify that the member for Paterson certainly knew Mr Geoghegan well before that time.

The member for Paterson attempted to refute my claim that a sweetheart deal was done on the lease by claiming that the building was actually purpose-built for Hills Solicitors, a well-known Maitland firm. In fact, the member for Paterson has dug himself much deeper because it is now revealed that Hills were not happy with the design of the building and reneged on the deal before the lease was signed. So Mr Geoghegan of course was left with a new building but no tenant. Happily for Mr Geoghegan, the member for Paterson happened along and gave up a lease in Church Street, Maitland, at $35,000 per annum to take up residence in Mr Geoghegan's building in East Maitland for some $55,000 per annum. Mr Geoghegan must have been so pleased to have the member for Paterson on board.

I want to return to the failed application for a Dairy RAP grant by Mr Sepos. The member for Paterson claims he was making representation on behalf of Mr Sepos as the then Liberal candidate for the seat of Paterson, yet insiders told me he approached the HACC as `a lobbyist'. This implies that the member for Paterson was actually being paid for his services, just as he was paid for his work in securing a number of other grants from the Howard government for projects in the electorate, including the Impulse call centre.

The member for Paterson's most outrageous claim earlier today was that an application from Sepos for Dairy RAP funding was never submitted. That is not true. An application was submitted, but unfortunately it was submitted incomplete. The member for Paterson first attempted to lodge the application himself but was told quite clearly by the executive officer of the HACC that that would not be appropriate. After strongly protesting, the member for Paterson had Sepos himself submit the application, albeit incomplete. After a number of attempts on the HACC's behalf to have the application completedâthey were keen to get on with the job, because the member for Paterson was putting on all this pressureâon November 1 2001 Sepos advised the HACC that he was in no position to complete the application because he was awaiting an assurance from Dungog council that he would be given facilities for free.

I will say this for the member for Paterson: he does not let his mates down. He did not let Bob Geoghegan down when he was desperate for a tenant. The deal worked out pretty nicely for Mr Geoghegan, because he sold the building later on with the lease secure from DOFA, a very nice little earner, adding significant value to the building. And he did not let Mr Sepos down when he went looking for a grant. One thing is certain: what the member for Paterson failed to do today was sufficiently and adequately address the questions I posed in this place last Thursday: what was the nature of the deal on the tenancy? More importantly, what was his role in the sacking of Arch Humphrey in his attempt to secure Dairy RAP funding for Sepos? More importantly, what conversations did he have with Ministers Anderson and Tuckey to secure the sacking of Mr Humphrey? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on ocean outfall both within my electorate and nationally, and I will do so in three phases. Firstly, I will look at the problem of ocean outfall at Boag's Rocks on Gunnamatta Beach, within my electorate. Currently, 420 megalitresâthat is, 420 million litresâof water flow from the Eastern Treatment Plant in Carrum Downs, underneath the Mornington Peninsula and out at Boag's Rocks on Gunnamatta Beach. The result is threefold. Firstly, health risks are created, and the local surfing community make it very clear that significant health problems flow from the outfall. Secondly, there is clear damage to the marine and coastal environments within that area. Thirdly, there is significant economic waste. The wasted water and other products could be used rather than sent out to sea.

speech.para: I believe there is only one acceptable outcome for water from the Eastern Treatment Plant. Ultimately, three things would occur. Firstly, there would be an increase in the reuse of water at source, within the home. Secondly, there would be an upgrade to potable level of the quality of the water coming out of the treatment plant. Thirdly, all of the water would be used and recycled, ending the problem of ocean outfall. This is a realistic and feasible outcome, as the Clean Ocean Foundation indicates, but it will take time. We must push towards a clear and absolute closure of the outfall.

Secondly, there is the notion of governance over different horizons, and there are three phases of governance. Firstly, there are many issues we seek to resolve within the three-year period of the cycle of government. They include economic questions and questions relating to social welfare. Secondly, there are questions we need to deal with over a decade: questions about the nature of education and about the provision of different elements of our work force. There is a lead time for those. Thirdly, there are issues which must be resolved over a generation. I put the case for the creation of a national ocean outfall strategy aimed at ending the waste of water at 142 ocean outfalls throughout Australia by the year 2025. This is a plan for a generational approach to ending the waste of water.

Six steps need to be taken in order to bring to fruition this plan for a national ocean outfall strategy. The first is to create a proper valuation of the potential revenueâwhich we are currently forgoingâfrom the recovery of commercially saleable fats and oils, metals, solid wastes and, above all else, recycled water. If we were to do that, we would understand the economic value of that which is currently being wasted. That understanding occurs in other countries. Although water is a responsibility of the statesâand I believe that all of the states are failing in their responsibilities to address this valuable resourceâat a national level, we have to take the lead and say, `These questions are not being addressed.'

The second is to identify the best practice global technology to upgrade waste water to A-grade, potable quality water. This has been done in Israel, in many other parts of the developed world and throughout the Middle East, where there is a critical water shortage. We are facing that shortage and it is something we have to address. We have to assess the cost of capital works for this; we have to assess the level of demand; we have to identify opportunities for private and public partnerships as a means of delivering the technical expertise; and we have to assess the capacity to use this water in many of the proposals for inland schemes. I am not saying that these options are viable but we have to consider them at a national level, because the states are failing to do that. This is governance on a generational scale; 25 years from now, the generation to come will need to have had those questions addressed by us. We must begin that process, and I call for a national ocean outfall strategy. I praise the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, who has indicated his interest in questions of water use in the long term. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIt is a privilege to rise in the adjournment debate to talk about the situation in the southern suburbs of Brisbane, in my local community, and about the things that are affecting people most at a local level as a result of policies being taken or not taken at the central level, in Canberra. Out in Australia at the moment, one of the big issues in local community life is bulk-billing and affordability of local health services for average families on average incomes. In my electorate in the last 12 months, we have seen a 6.2 per cent drop in the number of doctors providing bulk-billing services. In September 2000, 74 per cent of my local GPs provided bulk-billing services; by December 2001, that had dropped to 69 per cent.

speech.para: My office recently telephoned around to see how many GPs in my local area were still providing bulk-billing services. We found that, having rung 37 of them, only 26 were still providing bulk-billing services. The story our local GPs have to tell is, I think, a story being told across Australia today. Two things are affecting them most. The first is that the Medicare payments they receive from the Commonwealth government have not kept pace with the costs of running their own local medical practices. The second is that, on top of that, there is a new cost in the form of medical indemnity insurance. There are many GPs in my part of Brisbane who have been practising there for donkey's years and who are now ringing me and saying, `I'm tossing in the towel altogether; I'm closing my practice. It's getting too much.' It is a story I hear in each city and town of Australia that I visit. Something has to be done about this, because it is a crisis affecting local families and local communities, for whom bulk-billing provided through our national Medicare system has been a mainstay in the provision of basic health services to families in need.

Mr Ron Smith of Bulimba in my electorate came to me recently and said that, because of the abolition of bulk-billing, it is costing him an additional $12 per visit, which adds up to hundreds of dollars extra per year. There are other examples that I have picked up in my many mobile offices across Brisbane's southside. This is where a philosophy of withdrawing basic government attention to health and education services at a local level bites hard for communities in need of basic health services.

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted.
to move:

motion.para: That this House:
(1) notes the serious state of drought across the south eastern part of the Australian continent;
(2) recognises the variability of weather patterns across Australia;
(3) recognises the serious economic and social impact being felt by rural communities;
(4) acknowledges the need to maintain the long term viability of agriculture in the drought affected regions; and
(5) calls on State Governments to provide a more substantial financial contribution to drought relief.

talk.start.para: to present a bill for an act to assess certain windfall amounts not paid to the States as tobacco franchise fees or to the Commonwealth as tobacco excise and for related purposes.
to move:

motion.para: That this House:
(1) recognises the need to ease traffic congestion on the New England Highway to assist motorists from areas such as Beresfield and Thornton;

(2) acknowledges a recent audit of the New England Highway by the NRMA which found the worst section of the highway is a 12.8km stretch between Hexham and Maitland which includes the Weakley's Drive intersection;
(3) further acknowledges the audit which found that this particular stretch of road has a crash and casualty rate 79% higher than the route average;
(4) recognises the most recent fatality on the New England Highway when a motorist was killed on the South Seas Drive intersection in August 2002; and
(5) calls on all levels of government to progress work along this highway as quickly as possible, including:
(a) State Government construction of a link road between Beresfield and Thornton;
(b) construction of an interchange at the Weakley's Drive intersection; and
(c) funding of improvements to intersections along the highway that have an historically high rate of accidents.

business.start.para: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. I.R. Causley) took the chair at 8.00 p.m.

debateinfo.title: RESEARCH INVOLVING EMBRYOS AND PROHIBITION OF HUMAN CLONING BILL 2002

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 22 August, on motion by Mr Howard:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
That further proceedings on this bill be conducted in the House.

talk.start.para: âYou have resolved, have you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the proceedings not be further conducted in the House.
(Hon. I.R. Causley)âYes.
âIn that case, I move:

motion.para: That the Deputy Speaker's ruling be dissented from.

speech.para: Mr Deputy Speaker, I move this motion because it is incapable of the Main Committee to pass such a resolution on the basis that the way in which this bill was sent to the Main Committee by the House is contrary to standing orders. On that basis, the Main Committee can do nothing other than refer the bill back to the House.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)âThe question is that my ruling be dissented from. My ruling on it would be that, under the standing orders of the Main Committee, if there is a disagreement over a resolution in the Main Committee then the bill is set aside and dealt with in the House.

âAs I understand it, there has been no disagreement over a resolution. I moved that further proceedings be conducted in the House. You called that that had been defeated, despite the fact that there were three on this side supporting that motion and two on the other side from whom there was no dissenting voice. So the question of an unresolved question does not arise. The Main Committee having passed the resolution that the bill not be returned to the House, I have taken a point of order and the point of order is that the Main Committee is not capable of resolving in that way because the basis on which the bill was sent to the Main Committee is outside the standing orders. That is the point of order I have taken.

âThe standing orders of the Main Committee are that you cannot resolve an issue in this committee. I therefore rule the question is unresolved and the matter will be referred to the House. However, in accordance with the resolution agreed to by the House earlier today, debate on the bill will continue regardless of any unresolved question.

âMr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: do I now understand what you are ruling is that my motion to return the matter to the House so that further proceedings be conducted in the House is an unresolved question?

âWhat I am ruling is that the standing orders say that a question that cannot be resolved in the Main Committee must be referred to the House. I am ordering that this is an unresolved question and will be referred to the House.
âMy point of order is that it is not an unresolved question. If you look at standing order 276, it states:

quote.para: Every question in the Committee shall be decided on the voices and if any Member dissents from the result announced by the Chair, the question shall be recorded in the minutes as unresolved.

interjection.para: No member dissented.

talk.start.para: âThat is correct. That is exactly what I have ruled.
âNo member dissented.
âIt is unresolved, so it will be decided by the House because the Main Committee cannot resolve the question.
âMy point of order is on standing order 276, headed `How questions decidedâDivision not possible'. It states:

quote.para: Every question in the Committee shall be decided on the voices and if any Member dissents from the result announced by the Chair, the question shall be recorded in the minutes as unresolved.

interjection.para: No member dissented from the result announced by the chair. The matter was resolved.

talk.start.para: âI ruled in the negative. There is no point of order.
âMr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: your ruling, as I understand it, is that my motion that further proceedings be conducted in the House is an unresolved question.
âIt will be resolved in the House.
âMr Deputy Speaker, I have moved dissent from your ruling.

interjection.para: Question unresolved.

talk.start.para: âThe ayes have it.
âI asked for the ayes and I did not hear any. The question is unresolved, so I will refer it to the House.
âI rise on the point of order.
âI asked for all those in favour and there were none.
âYou ruled that my dissent was not carried and I called dissent to that.
âThere were no voices.
âI called it.
âThere is no point of order.

âMr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: I moved dissent from your ruling. That was put; you ruled that it was not carried. I raised my voice in accordance with standing order 276 and indicated that it was an unresolved question.
âAnd I accommodated you by saying that it will be referred to the House.

âBut it needs to be referred to the House now. Under standing orders 270 and 276, a dissent from your ruling has to be referred to the House now. It is a dissent from your ruling. It is not covered in any way by the resolution of the House in respect of the bill the House is dealing with, which deems that any unresolved issue be treatedâ
âIt is not an unresolved question.
âOrder! I remind the member for Perth of the resolution agreed to by the House before the dinner suspension and point (4) of that says:

quote.para: ... the Main Committee continuing debate on the Bill regardless of any unresolved questions.

talk.start.para: â`The Main Committee continuing debate on the bill regardless of any unresolved questions'. This is not `on the bill'; this is a dissent from your ruling. This is an unresolved question on a ruling made by you. It is not covered by the resolution passed by the House.
âAs far as I am concerned it is. There is no point of order.
âPoint of order, Mr Deputy Speaker.
âYou have not sat down yet.
âI will sit down and I will wait for you to call me on a point of order.
âThe member for Perth on a point of order.

âIn accordance with standing order 270 and standing order 276, if one voice is raised in dissent from a chair's ruling, the matter is unresolved and returned to the House immediately. They are the standing orders. A resolution passed by the House prior to dinner does not cover a ruling of the chair and does not cover a motion of dissent from your ruling. It only deals with the bill. Your ruling has been challenged. That is an unresolved question. It must be referred to the House now.

âWhether it be a ruling on a point of order, or whether it be a ruling on dissent, I consider that it is a ruling and the fact is that, under the orders that were resolved in the House, which say, `the Main Committee continuing debate on the Bill regardless of any unresolved questions,' this is an unresolved question. I will refer it to the House.
âIt needs to be referred to the House now.
âIt does not have to be referred to the House now.
âIn that case, Mr Deputy Speaker, I move:

motion.para: That the Main Committee has no confidence in the Chair.

speech.para: Question unresolved.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)âIt is an unresolved question. I will refer it to the House.
âMr Deputy Speaker, it has to be referred now.
âI said it is an unresolved question.
âThe ayes have it.
âI heard the ayes and I heard the noes and I ruled that the noes have it.
âMy point of order is this: there is an unresolved question in respect of the confidence that the Main Committee has in the chair.
âDo you want to move another motion?
âI have moved a motion.
âI have said that the motion is unresolved. I have referred it to the House.

interjection.para: Mr STEPHEN SMITH (Perth) (8.08 p.m.)âI move:

motion.para: That that matter be referred to the House forthwith.

interjection.para: Question unresolved.

talk.start.para: âIt is an unresolved question. I will refer it to the House.
âMr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: there are three unresolved questions.
âI have referred them to the House to be dealt with.

âFirstly, there is the dissent motion. Secondly, there is the motion for want of confidence in you. Thirdly, there is the motion that that want of confidence be referred to the House forthwith. On what basis do you say that cannot be referred to the House? It has to be referred to the House forthwith.
âOn the basis of the motion that was moved earlier in the House and carried by the House.
âThe House's resolution does not say anything about want of confidence in the chair.
âIt says if there are any unresolved questions they will be referred to the Houseâ
âIn respect of the bill. Whether the committee has confidence in you or not has nothing to do with the bill. The House's resolution does not cover it!
âThe member for Perth will resume his seat!

interjection.para: Mrs GASH (Gilmore) (8.10 p.m.)âI move:

motion.para: That the member be not further heard.

interjection.para: Question unresolved.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. There are four unresolved questions now.
âThey will all be resolved by the House.

âNone of them are covered by the motion passed by the House, which referred to the bill. There is an unresolved question in respect of dissent from your ruling. There is an unresolved question in respect of want of confidence in the chair. There is an unresolved question in respect of that want of confidence being referred to the House immediately. There is an unresolved question in respect of whether the member for Perth be not further heard. All those issues need to be referred to the House now, because the motion that was passed before dinner in the House referred to debate on the bill.
âDo you have another point of order?
âYou must act now. You have no choice; you must act now.
âYou have no point of order. I have ruled on all of those.
âMr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: this is quite an outrageous performance by the opposition. The motion that was carried in the House is very clear. It says:

quote.para: ... the Main Committee continuing debate on the Bill regardless of any unresolved questions.

interjection.para: What we are trying to do as a government is to facilitate government members continuing debate on this issue.

talk.start.para: âI have heard the point of order. The member for Robertson will resume his seat. I have ruled on that point of order.
âMr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. My point of order is very precise. The motion provided by the House says:

quote.para: ... following arrangements applying in relation to the Research Involving Embryos and Prohibition of Human Cloning Bill 2002 ...

interjection.para: It is nothing to do with the substantial procedural issues that the member for Perth has been raising and disagreeing with you on. His point is valid: this should be returned to the House forthwith.

talk.start.para: âI remind the member for Lilley of point (4), and I will take him to the third last word, which says `any' unresolved questions will be referred to the House.

âIt is clearly subsidiary to the lead paragraph in the motion passed by the House. The lead paragraph relates only to the Research Involving Embryos and Prohibition of Human Cloning Bill 2002. If the parliament had wished this to extend to procedural matters of the Main Committee, that would have been included in the motion passed by the House.
âThere is no point of order. You are debating the issue.

âMr Deputy Speaker, how can you rule, as you have, that dissent from the chair on procedural mattersâwhere a clear majority of people in the Main Committee dissent from your rulingâis considered under point (4) of the resolution that you are quoting as to not refer this back to the House? This is a clear abuse of the democratic process.
âThat is exactly what you are doing and you should be ashamed.
âI am not ashamed about this, because the majority of the members in the chamber should be able to decide what the procedure of this chamber is.

âThe member for Melbourne Ports will resume his seat. I have heard his point of order. The standing orders say that, if the Main Committee cannot resolve a question, it is referred to the House. I have referred the unresolved questions to the House.
âMr Deputy Speaker, they clearly do not resolveâ
âDo you have a point of order?

âI certainly do. The motion passed by the House of Representatives earlier this evening clearly does not go to the procedural matters that are currently being contested on the floor. As I said to you before, (1), (2) and (3)âthe subsets of the overall motion passedârelate only to the bill. They do not relate to procedural matters, otherwise those standing ordersâ
âThere is no point of order. The member for Lilley is debatingâ
âMr Deputy Speaker, will you let me finish?
âNo. The member for Lilley is debating the issue. I said that there is no point of order.
âYou have not heard me out yet.
âThere is no point of order; you will resume your seat.

âOn that, I will take a point of order. The point of order is very simple: there are specific standing orders which relate to procedures which are not mentioned in the motion that has been passed by the House of Representatives earlier this evening. They are not mentioned at all and therefore they are clearly outside the ambit of your ruling.
